(11)  An applicant has been employed in a dance hall within the preceding 12 months and has demonstrated an inability to operate or manage a dance hall premises in a peaceful and law abiding manner. 
(12)  Alcoholic beverages are possessed, consumed, or sold on premises used or to be used by the applicant for a Class E dance hall. 
(13)  An applicant for a Class E dance hall license is in violation of the locational requirements of section 11A-42. 
(14)  An applicant for a Class D dance hall license is in violation of the locational requirements of section 11A-43. 
(b)  The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on the disqualification of the applicant or the applicant's spouse. 
(c)  An applicant who has been convicted or whose spouse has been convicted of an offense listed in subsection (a)(10)a. may qualify for a dance hall license only when the time period required by subsection (a)(10)b. has elapsed. 
(d)  The license shall state on its face the name of the person to whom it is granted, the expiration date, the address of the dance hall, and whether it is issued for a Class A, Class B, Class C, Class D, or Class E dance hall. 
(e)  The license, along with any late hours permit, shall be posted, in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance to the dance hall so that it may be easily read at any time. 
Sec. 11A-46. - Late hours permit. 
(a)  A person who is issued a Class A, Class B, Class C, or Class D dance hall license may apply, on a form provided by the chief of police, for a late hours permit. Upon receipt of the application and payment of the late hours permit fee, the chief of police shall issue a later hours permit to the applicant. 
(b)  Once issued, a late hours permit is considered a part of the license for a Class A, Class B, Class C, or Class D dance hall and is valid only when the dance hall license it accompanies is valid. 
Sec. 11A-47. - Fees. 
    Nonrefundable fees established by resolution of the city council shall be charged for each license and late hours permit issued under the terms of this article. 
Sec. 11A-48. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  A person without a late hours permit commits an offense if he operates a Class A, Class B, Class C, or Class D dance hall between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. Monday through Saturday, or between 2:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon on Sunday. 
(b)  A person with a late hours permit commits an offense if he operates a Class A, Class B, Class C, or Class D dance hall between the hours of 4:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday, or between 4:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon Sunday. 
(c)  A person commits an offense if he operates a Class E dance hall during any hours other than the following: 
(1)  When school is in session in the school district in which the dance hall is located, between the hours of: 
a.  4:00 p.m. and 10:00 p.m., Monday through Thursday; 
b.  4:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight, Friday; 
c.  1:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight, Saturday; and 
d.  1:00 p.m. and 10:00 p.m., Sunday; or 
(2)  When school is not in session in the school district in which the dance hall is located, between the hours of 1:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight, Monday through Sunday. 
Sec. 11A-49. - Inspection. 
(a)  Representatives of the police, health, fire and public works departments may inspect the premises of a dance hall, for the purpose of insuring compliance with the law, at any time it is open for business or occupied. 
(b)  A person who operates a dance hall or a person designated as the dance hall supervisor commits an offense if he refuses to permit a lawful inspection of the premises of a dance hall by a representative of the police department or authorized representative at any time it is open for business or occupied. 
Sec. 11A-50. - Dance hall supervisor. 
(a)  A person who operates a dance hall must designate a person as dance hall supervisor and register that person's name with the chief of police. 
(b)  A person designated dance hall supervisor must remain on the premises of the dance hall during the time dancing is permitted and until 30 minutes after the end of the dance to insure that the dance is conducted in an orderly manner. 
Sec. 11A-51. - Persons under 17 prohibited. 
(a)  No person under the age of 17 years may enter a Class A, Class B, or Class C dance hall unless accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he falsely represents himself to be either a parent or guardian of a person under the age of 17 years for the purpose of gaining the person's admittance into a Class A, Class B, or Class C dance hall. 
(c)  A licensee or employee of a Class A, Class B, or Class C dance hall commits an offense if he knowingly allows a person under the age of 17 years to enter or remain on the premises of the dance hall unless the person is accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(d)  A licensee of a Class A, Class B, or Class C dance hall commits an offense if he maintains the premises without posting a sign at each entrance to the business that reads: "It is unlawful for any person under 17 years old to enter this location without a parent or guardian." 
Sec. 11A-52. - Persons under 14 and over 18 prohibited. 
(a)  No person under the age of 14 or over the age of 18 may enter a Class E dance hall. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he is over the age of 18 years and: 
(1)  Enters a Class E dance hall; or 
(2)  For the purpose of gaining admittance into a Class E dance hall, he falsely represents himself to be: 
a.  Of an age from 14 years through 18 years; 
b.  A licensee or an employee of the dance hall; 
c.  A parent or guardian of a person inside the dance hall; or 
d.  A governmental employee in the performance of official duties. 
(c)  A licensee or an employee of a Class E dance hall commits an offense if he knowingly allows a person to enter or remain on the premises of the dance hall who is: 
(1)  Under the age of 14 years; or 
(2)  Over the age of 18 years. 
(d)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsections (b)(1) and (c)(1) above that the person is: 
(1)  A licensee or employee of the dance hall; 
(2)  A parent or guardian of a person inside the dance hall; or 
(3)  A governmental employee in the performance of official duties. 
(e)  A licensee of a Class E dance hall commits an offense if he maintains the premises without posting a sign at each entrance to the dance hall that reads: "It is unlawful for any person under 14 years old to enter this location without a parent or guardian. It is unlawful for any person over 18 years old to enter this location." 
Sec. 11A-53. - Persons under 18 prohibited. 
(a)  No person under the age of 18 years may enter a Class D dance hall. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he falsely represents himself to be a person 18 years of age or older for the purpose of gaining admittance into a Class D dance hall. 
(c)  A licensee or employee of a Class D dance hall commits an offense if he knowingly allows a person under the age of 18 years to enter or remain on the premises of the dance hall. 
(d)  A licensee of a Class D dance hall commits an offense if he maintains the premises without posting a sign at each entrance to the dance hall that reads: "It is unlawful for any person under 18 years old to enter this location." 
Sec. 11A-54. - Expiration of license. 
(a)  A license for a Class A, Class B, Class D, or Class E dance hall expires one year from the date of issuance and may be renewed only by making application as provided in section 11A-41. Application for renewal should be made at least 30 days before the expiration date, and when made less than 30 days before the expiration date, the expiration of the license will not be affected. 
(b)  A late hours permit for a Class A, Class B, Class C, or Class D dance hall expires in conjunction with the accompanying dance hall license and may be renewed only by making application as provided in section 11A-46. 
(c)  A license for a Class C dance hall expires at 2:00 a.m., or 4:00 a.m., if a late hours permit has been issued, on the day following the date of the dance. 
(d)  When the chief of police denies renewal of a license, the applicant shall not be issued a license for one year from the date denial becomes final. If subsequent to denial, the chief of police finds that the basis for denial of the renewal license has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a license if at least 90 days have elapsed since the date denial became final. If a renewal of a license is denied under subsection 11A-45(a)(13) only, the applicant may be granted a license immediately upon compliance with section 11A-42. If a renewal of a license is denied under subsection 11A-45(a)(14) only, the applicant may be granted a license immediately upon compliance with section 11A-43. 
Sec. 11A-55. - Suspension. 
    The chief of police shall suspend a dance hall license for a period of time not exceeding 30 days if the chief of police determines that a licensee or an employee of a licensee has: 
(1)  Violated subsections 11A-45(4), 11A-48, 11A-51, 11A-52, 11A-53, or 11A-58 of this article; 
(2)  Engaged in excessive use of alcoholic beverages while on the dance hall premises; 
(3)  Refused to allow an inspection of the dance hall premises as authorized in this article; 
(4)  Knowingly permitted an intoxicated person to remain on the premises; 
(5)  Knowingly permitted gambling by any person on the dance hall premises; 
(6)  Demonstrated inability to operate or manage a dance hall premises in a peaceful and law abiding manner, thus necessitating action by law enforcement officers; or 
(7)  Knowingly permitted the possession, consumption, or sale of an alcoholic beverage on the premises of a Class E dance hall. 
Sec. 11A-56. - Revocation. 
(a)  The chief of police shall revoke a license if a cause of suspension in section 11A-55 occurs and the license has been suspended within the preceding 12 months. 
(b)  The chief of police shall revoke a license if the chief of police determines that one or more of the following is true: 
(1)  A licensee has given false or misleading information in the material submitted to the chief of police during the application process. 
(2)  A licensee or an employee is unable to lawfully operate the dance hall because of physical or mental impairment. 
(3)  A licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed possession, use or sale of controlled substances on the premises. 
(4)  A licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed prostitution on the premises. 
(5)  A licensee or an employee knowingly permitted dancing or a live performance during a period of time when the dance hall license was suspended. 
(6)  A licensee has been: 
a.  Convicted of an offense listed in subsection 11A-45(b) for which the time period required in subsection 11A-45(b) has not elapsed; or 
b.  Convicted of or is under indictment for any felony offense while holding a dance hall license. 
(7)  While an employee of the dance hall and while on the licensed premises, a person has committed an offense listed in subsection 11A-45(a) for which a conviction has been obtained, two or more times within a 12-month period. 
(8)  A licensee of a Class E dance hall is in violation of the locational requirements of section 11A-42. 
(9)  A licensee of a Class D dance hall is in violation of the locational requirements of section 11A-42. 
(c)  The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on the revocation of the license. 
(d)  When the chief of police revokes a license, the revocation shall continue for one year and the licensee shall not be issued a dance hall license for one year from the date revocation became final. If, subsequent to revocation, the chief of police finds that the basis for the revocation action has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a license if at least 90 days have elapsed since the date the revocation became final. If the license was revoked under subsection (b)(8) above only, the applicant may be granted a license immediately upon compliance with section 11A-42. If the license was revoked under subsection (b)(9) above only, the applicant may be granted a license immediately upon compliance with section 11A-43. If the license was revoked under subsection (b)(7) above, an applicant may not be granted another license until the appropriate number of years required under subsection 11A-45(a) has elapsed. 
Sec. 11A-57. - Appeals. 
(a)  If the chief of police denies the issuance of a license, or suspends or revokes a license, the chief of police shall send to the applicant, or licensee, by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of the action and the right to an appeal. The aggrieved party may appeal the decision of the chief of police to the board of adjustment. The filing of an appeal stays the action of the chief of police in suspending or revoking a license until the board makes a final decision. If within a ten day period the chief of police suspends, revokes, or denies issuance of a sexually oriented business license for the same location involved in the chief's actions on the dance hall license, then the chief may consolidate the request for appeals of those actions into one appeal. This subsection shall not apply to a Class D dance hall license. 
(b)  If the chief of police denies the issuance of a Class D dance hall license, or suspends or revokes a Class D dance hall license, the chief of police shall send to the applicant, or licensee, by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of the action and the right to an appeal. Upon receipt of written notice of the denial, suspension, or revocation, the licensee whose application for a license has been denied or whose license has been suspended or revoked shall have the right to appeal to the state district court. An appeal to the state district court must be filed within 30 days after the receipt of notice of the decision of the chief of police. The licensee shall bear the burden of proof in court. 
Sec. 11A-58. - Transfer of license or late hours permit. 
    A licensee shall not transfer a license or late hours permit to another, nor shall a licensee operate a dance hall under the authority of a license, or a late hours permit, at any place other than the address designated in the application. 
Sec. 11A-59. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of sections 11A-40 to 11A-58, except sections 11A-42 or 11A-43, upon conviction is punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. Any person who violated section 11A-42 or 11A-43 of this article, upon conviction, is punishable by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00. 
Sec. 11A-60. - Injunction. 
    A person who operates or causes to be operated a dance hall without a valid license or in violation of sections 11A-42 or 11A-43 of this article is subject to a suit for injunction as well as prosecution for criminal violations. 
(Ord. No. 1360, § 1, 11-1-93; Ord. No. 1363, § 1, 11-22-93) 
Chapter 11B - SEX CLUB REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 11B-1. - Title. 
    These regulations shall be known as the Duncanville Sex Club Ordinance, may be cited as such, and will be referred to herein as "this chapter". 
(Ord. No. 2039, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 11B-2. - Purpose and scope. 
(a)  The purpose of this chapter is to promote public health, safety and welfare by regulating the activities of sex clubs in the City of Duncanville. 
(b)  The regulations of this chapter are not intended to permit any violations of the provisions of any other law. 
(c)  In the event of conflicts, actual or perceived, in the terms or requirements of this chapter, the most restrictive interpretation shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2039, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 11B-3. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Authority. The Building Official of the City of Duncanville is hereby authorized and directed to enforce all the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Right of entry. Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of this chapter, or whenever the building official has probable cause after obtaining an administrative warrant to believe that a there exists in any building or upon any premises any condition which violates the provisions of this chapter, the building official may enter such building or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed upon the building official by this chapter. If such building or premises is occupied, the building official shall first present proper credentials and request entry; and if such premises is unoccupied, the building official shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other persons having charge or control of the building or premises and request entry. If such entry is refused, the building official shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry. 
(Ord. No. 2039, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 11B-4. - Responsibility for compliance. 
    Any owner, tenant, person or persons in charge of a premises; occupant, guest, visitor, patron, member; or person or persons having beneficial use of a property upon which a sex club is located, are all subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2039, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 11B-5. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Building official. The Building Official of the City of Duncanville or the building official's authorized representative. 
    City. The City of Duncanville, Texas. 
    Consideration. Any exchange of money, an item of value, or service requested, solicited, provided, or bargained for in connection with: 
(1)  Gaining entrance or the right to remain on a premises, or any portion thereof; 
(2)  Obtaining an item or any marking permitting entrance or the right to remain on a premises, or any portion thereof; or 
(3)  A membership or other form of affiliation permitting the right to enter or remain on a premises, or any portion thereof. 
    Donation. Any act or instance of presenting money, an item of value, or a service as a grant or contribution in association with the availability of some benefit, including but not limited to a good or service, admission or access to a location or event, or use of facilities. 
    Operate and maintain. To organize, manage, control, design, perpetuate, publicize, invite, or solicit. Operate and maintain includes providing financial support by paying utilities, rent, maintenance costs, or advertising costs; providing food, beverages, or other entertainment; supervising activities or work schedules, and directing or furthering the aims of the enterprise or organization. 
    Person. A person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, group, organization or entity of any kind. 
    Premises. Any and all parts of a property, structure or location on, in or at which a sex club is operated. 
    Sexual contact. Contact with the male or female genitalia or anus, or the female breast by any part of the human body. 
    Sex club. Any organization or real property and its improvements advertised, promoted, or presented as a location where for a solicited fee, donation, or other consideration, there is an opportunity or invitation to engage in or to observe sexual activity. 
    Sexual activity. Any activity that includes sexual intercourse or sexual contact. 
    Sexual intercourse. Penetration into the male or female genitalia or anus by any part of the body, or by any object; or manual masturbatory contact with the male or female genitalia or anus. 
(Ord. No. 2039, § 1, 11-6-07; Ord. No. 2051, §§ 2, 3, 5-6-08) 
Sec. 11B-6. - Operation and maintenance of a sex club declared a public nuisance and prohibited. 
    The operation and maintenance of a sex club is unlawful and a nuisance per se. 
(Ord. No. 2039, § 1, 11-6-07; Ord. No. 2051, § 4, 5-6-08) 
Sec. 11B-7. - Abatement of public nuisance. 
(a)  The building official may order any person operating and maintaining a sex club to immediately cease such operation and maintenance, and require patrons to vacate the premises. The order abating the nuisance shall be in writing, and may be served in person, by certified or regular mail, or by posting the order on the premises. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to apply to the presentation, showing or performance of any play, drama or ballet in any theater, concert hall, fine arts academy, school, institution of higher education or similar establishment holding a certificate of occupancy from the city, as a form of expression of opinion or communication of ideas or information. 
(Ord. No. 2039, § 1, 11-6-07; Ord. No. 2051, § 5, 5-6-08) 
Sec. 11B-7a. - Appeal. 
    On receipt of a written order to cease operation and maintenance of a sex club, the owner, tenant, or person in charge of or having beneficial use of the premises shall have the right to appeal to the board of adjustment of the city. The board of adjustment on the filing of such an appeal shall conduct a hearing and take evidence as to whether a sex club is being operated in violation of this article. The chair of the board of adjustment may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. Minutes and records of the examinations and evidence presented during the hearing must be kept and filed as public record. The decision of the board of adjustment is final, and any appeal of the decision must be made to the district court within 30 days after receipt of the written notice of the decision of the board of adjustment. The district court's review shall be limited to a hearing under the substantial evidence rule. Costs may not be allowed against the city or the board of adjustments. 
(Ord. No. 2051, § 6, 5-6-08) 
Sec. 11B-8. - Penalty. 
    It is the city's intent that all acts in violation of this article occurring within the city shall be prosecuted as a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00. Each person, firm, corporation, or partnership shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or any portion thereof during which any violation of the provisions of this article is committed, or continued by such person, firm, corporation, or partnership, and shall be deemed punishable thereof as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2039, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Chapter 12 - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES AND PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- General provisions, ch. 1; administration, ch. 2; ambulances, ch. 3; garbage and trash, ch. 10; municipal court, ch. 3; police, ch. 15; streets and sidewalks, ch. 17; traffic, ch. 19. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 832, § 2, enacted June 15, 1981, repealed § 12-1, relative to swimming and boating in city park lakes. Said section was derived from Ord. No. 368, §§ 1-3, adopted Apr. 8, 1966. 
Sec. 12-2. - Reserved. 
Sec. 12-3. - Loud and raucous noise. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, cause or allow to be made any unreasonably loud or raucous noise within the city which may be offensive to a reasonable person of normal sensitivity within the area of audibility. 
(b)  The following acts are deemed to create unreasonably loud or raucous noise and shall be deemed a violation of this section, but such enumeration shall not be deemed exclusive: 
(1)  The playing of any horn, radio, musical instrument or other loud-speaking or noise-making device or attachment, or vocal shouting or outcry for purposes of selling anything, in a public or private place, in such a manner or volume as to disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of a reasonable person of normal sensitivity. It shall be a defense to an offense charged under this subsection if the noise results from or is caused by the usual and reasonable operation of railroads, the reasonable use of automobile warning signals or horns, the reasonable ringing of church bells, or the reasonable or ordinary noises attendant upon athletic contests or lawful public or semipublic meetings, parades, celebrations or children at play. 
(2)  The playing of any horn, radio, musical instrument, or other loud-speaking or noise-making device or attachment on any premises under the ownership, management or control of such person, when such premises are being used as a place of business, in such a manner or volume as to disturb the peace or to be unreasonably offensive to reasonable persons of normal sensitivity in the vicinity or occupants of other premises in the vicinity. 
(3)  To create, make, cause or allow to be made by any means any loud and disturbing noise which may disturb a reasonable person of normal sensitivity in the vicinity of any public or private place after 10:00 p.m. and before 7:00 a.m. 
(4)  To be operating or in control of a motor vehicle in either a public or private place within the city while playing any sound amplifier which is part of, or connected to, the vehicle stereo system or any other similar device in the motor vehicle, in such a manner that when operated, it is audible at a distance of 30 feet from the source or causes a reasonable person of normal sensitivity to be aware of the vibration accompanying the sound at a distance of 30 feet from the source. 
(Ord. No. 478, § 1-3, 7-13-70; Ord. No. 1062, § 1, 4-7-86; Ord No. 1794, § 1, 7-16-02) 
Sec. 12-4. - Swimming, fishing in "Blue Hole"; hours restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to swim at any time or fish during the hours from 9:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. in that portion of Ten Mile Creek within the city known as "Blue Hole." 
(Ord. No. 478, § 4, 7-13-70) 
Editor's note- Sections 1-4, Ord. No. 478, adopted July 13, 1970, being not specifically amendatory of this Code, were originally codified as §§ 12-3 and 12-4 at the discretion of the editors. Subsequently, Ord. No. 1062, § 1, adopted Apr. 7, 1986, specifically amended § 12-3 to read as currently set out. 
Sec. 12-5. - Discharge of firearms, BB guns, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to discharge any firearm, rifle, shotgun, automatic rifle, revolver, pistol, pellet gun, BB gun, or any other device designed, made or adapted to expel a projectile, at any place, whether public or private, within the city limits. 
(1)  In any private place; 
(2)  On any private property; or 
(3)  On or across a public road. 
(b)  It is a defense to prosecution under this section that: 
(1)  The person was a law enforcement peace officer acting in the performance of his official duties; 
(2)  The person was at a shooting range operated by an agency of the United States government, State of Texas, or a political subdivision of the state or which is privately operated and approved by the police department; 
(3)  The person was using blank cartridges for a show or theatrical production, or for signal or ceremonial purposes in athletics or sports, or by a military organization. 
(Ord. No. 466, § 1, 3-23-70; Ord. No. 941, § 1, 2-6-84; Ord. No. 1911, § 1, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 12-6. - Placing trash or debris upon vacant lots or private property; failure to remove. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit any trash or debris upon any vacant lot or private property within the city. It shall also be unlawful for the owner or occupant to fail to remove trash or debris from any vacant lot or private property in the city after being requested to do so by an official of the city. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 2, 3-8-71) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 493, § 2, amended this Code by adding provisions designated as § 12-4 which provisions were redesignated § 12-6 by the editors. 
Cross reference- Placing trash, debris on or failing to remove from streets, alleys, easements, etc., § 17-3. 
Sec. 12-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 12-7, requiring adequate and convenient toilet facilities in food-service and food-processing establishments, was repealed by Ord. No. 870, § 1, enacted June 21, 1982. Said section was derived from Ord. No. 616, §§ 1-3, adopted Jan. 7, 1975. 
Sec. 12-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 12-8, relative to possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages in public parks, was repealed by Ord. No. 832, § 2, adopted June 15, 1981. Said section was derived from Ord. No. 721, §§ 1-5, enacted June 5, 1978. 
Sec. 12-9. - Occasional sales. 
(a)  An occasional sale, to include garage sales and patio sales, is defined as a sale of tangible personal property at retail in the corporate limits of the city by a person or persons who do not hold themselves out as engaging, or do not habitually engage, in the business of selling such tangible personal property at retail, providing that the tangible personal property shall be sold only on the premises of the owner or lessee of the property where the sale is conducted and that the owner or lessee must be legal owner of at least a portion of such tangible personal property at the time of the sale. Such sales shall be confined to the garage, patio or yard of such premises in residential areas only. Occasional sales shall not include new merchandise or merchandise acquired solely for the purpose of resale, and any holding out for sale or sales of such merchandise shall be a violation of this section. 
(b)  Occasional sales shall not exceed two in number during any six-month period, and the duration of each such sale shall not exceed four consecutive calendar days. 
(c)  Before any such occasional sale may be had by an owner or lessee as set out herein, a permit therefore shall be secured from the building inspector of the city. An application for such permit shall include the name, address and date of sale, and shall generally describe the merchandise to be sold. The first permit for a location may be issued by the building inspector during any calendar year without the payment of a fee. After the issuance of one permit without fee for a location during any calendar year, the building inspector shall collect a fee as established by resolution of the city council as it may determine from time to time, for each additional application during a calendar year for a permit to defray the expense of inspections and processing of such application. Upon approval of any such application, the building inspector shall issue an occasional sale permit to the applicant. All such permits so issued shall be numbered consecutively with the number assigned to each permit to be shown on the face of each permit. 
(d)  Every sign advertising an occasional sale shall clearly show on its face the permit number of the permit by which such occasional sale was authorized. All such signs shall be removed upon expiration of the aforesaid permit. Such signs shall not be erected within the public right-of-way or on the property of any other person without his permission. No such sign shall exceed the size of four square feet in area. 
(e)  Any person placing an advertisement of an occasional sale in any newspaper or other periodical publication, or in any handbill or similar advertising material, shall include in such advertisement, handbill or other advertising material a statement of the permit number of the permit by which such occasional sale was authorized. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 742, §§ 1-7, as amended, is included herein as § 12-9 at the discretion of the editors inasmuch as said ordinance did not expressly amend this Code. 
Sec. 12-10. - Riding or operating motor-driven vehicles of three wheels or less on vacant or unimproved property. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to ride or operate an all-terrain vehicle or a motor-driven vehicle of three wheels or less on any vacant or unimproved property within 1,000 feet of any developed property. 
(Ord. No. 966A, § 1, 7-16-84) 
Sec. 12-11. - Parking of vehicles for sale prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to stand or park a vehicle on any public street, parking lot, playground, athletic field, vacant lot, or public or private school for the principal purpose of displaying it for sale. 
(Ord. No. 1443, § 1, 1-8-96; Ord. No. 1505, § 1, 7-1-97) 
Secs. 12-12, 12-13. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENT SANITATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2264, § 1, adopted January 19, 2016, repealed art. II, §§ 12-14-12-34, in its entirety; and enacted a new art. II to read as set out herein. Former art. II pertained to similar subject matter, and was derived from Original Code and Ord. No. 1629, § 1, adopted February 15, 2000. 

Sec. 12-14. - Adoption of rules on food establishment sanitation. 
    The administrative rules as adopted by the state department of health, October 11, 2015, by 25 Texas Administrative Code §§ 228.1-228.278, Texas Retail Food (Rules) are hereby incorporated herein and adopted by reference as the food establishment sanitation regulations of the city, and a copy of said rules shall be kept on file in the office of the city secretary, and are hereby made a part of this Code for all purposes, the same as if fully copied herein. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-15. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the terms, phrases, words and derivation contained in the rules shall have the meaning given therein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. The provisions of this article and of said rules shall include retail food markets, which are defined as any establishment where food and food products are offered for sale to the ultimate consumer. The provisions of this article and of said rules shall also apply to food establishments which prepare food or food products on-site and operations such as grocery stores which have delicatessen operations and prepackaged sandwiches, coffee and fountain drinks. Such food or food products may be expected to vary in degree of preparation and may often need further preparation or processing after purchase. "regulatory authority" shall mean the city or its duly authorized officer, agent, or employee. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-16. - Valid health certification required. 
    No person shall operate a food establishment who does not have a valid health certificate issued to him by the regulatory authority. Only a person who complies with the requirements of this article shall be entitled to receive or retain such a health certificate. Health certificates are not transferable. A valid health certificate shall be posted in every food establishment in the city. A food establishment does not include an establishment that offers only prepackaged foods that are not time/temperature controlled for safety food, a produce stand that only offers whole, uncut fresh fruits and vegetables, a food processing plant, a cottage food industry, an area where cottage food is prepared, sold or offered for human consumption, a bed and breakfast limited facility, or a private home that receives catered or home-delivered food. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-17. - Issuance of health certificate. 
(a)  Any person desiring to operate a food establishment shall make written application for a health certificate on a form provided by the regulatory authority. Such application shall include the name and address of each applicant, the location and type of proposed food establishment, and the signature of the applicant. 
(b)  Prior to approval of an application for a health certificate, the regulatory authority shall inspect the proposed food establishment to determine compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(c)  The regulatory authority shall issue a health certificate to the applicant if upon inspection the proposed food establishment complies with the requirements of this article. 
(d)  All persons desiring to operate any food establishment in the city shall pay a health certificate fee as established by resolution of the city council as it may determine from time to time. All food establishments will be classified as follows: 
(1)  Class 1A shall include but not be limited to full service restaurants with dining area, and supermarkets without a deli/bakery located in the store. 
(2)  Class 2A shall include but not be limited to supermarkets with a deli/bakery located in the store, deli/bakery located in supermarkets, fast food establishments, small retail establishments (such as convenience stores, variety stores, video stores, mobile vendors, etc.), day care facilities and schools (private and public). 
(3)  Class 3A shall include but not be limited to seasonal establishments. 
(e)  All large retail stores will be assessed separate permit fees as established by resolution of the city council as it may determine from time to time for each operational function. 
(f)  All food establishments will be assessed a recheck fee as established by resolution of the city council as it may determine from time to time for each recheck conducted. 
(g)  Each individual temporary food establishment will be assessed a permit fees as established by resolution of the city council as it may determine from time to time. Each permit issued is only valid for the event for which it was issued. 
(h)  All food establishments will pay the required fee. In the event a food establishment has a change of ownership, a new application for a health certificate shall be required. 
(i)  All food establishments shall pay late fees as established by resolution of the city council as it may determine from time to time. 
(j)  The regulatory authority may, after providing opportunity for a hearing, close a food establishment if the owner of the establishment, or the person in charge, does not comply with the requirements of this article, or if the operation of the establishment does not comply with this article. Prior to closure, the regulatory authority shall notify, in writing, the owner or the person in charge of the specific reason for which the establishment is to be closed at the end of the ten days following the service of such notice. An opportunity for a hearing will be provided if a written request for a hearing is filed by the owner or person in charge with the regulatory authority within the ten-day period following the date on the notice. If a request for a hearing is received within the ten-day period, a hearing shall be held within 20 days following receipt of the request. If no request for a hearing is filed within the ten-day period, the closure of the food operation is sustained. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-18. - Suspension of health certificate. 
(a)  The regulatory authority may, without warning, prior notice or hearing, suspend any health certificate to operate a food establishment if the operation of the food establishment constitutes a substantial hazard to the public health or an imminent health hazard exists in the establishment. Suspension is effective immediately and the food service operation shall immediately cease. Whenever a health certificate is suspended immediately, the holder of the health certificate or the person in charge shall be informed in writing that the health certificate is immediately suspended and that an opportunity for a hearing will be provided if a written request is filed with the regulatory authority. The holder of the health certificate or the person in charge must file a written request for a hearing within ten days following closure. If a request for a hearing is received within the ten-day period, a hearing shall be held within 20 days of receipt of the request. If no request for a hearing is filed within the ten-day period, the suspension is sustained. The regulatory authority may end the suspension at any time if the reasons for the suspension no longer exist. 
(b)  The regulatory authority may, after providing opportunity for a hearing, suspend any health certificate to operate a food establishment if the holder of the health certificate does not comply with the requirements of this article or if the operation of the establishment does not comply with this article. Prior to suspension, the regulatory authority shall notify in writing the holder of the health certificate or the person in charge of the specific reason for which the health certificate is to be suspended at the end of the ten days following the service of such notice. An opportunity for a hearing will be provided if a written request is filed with the regulatory authority. The holder of the health certificate or the person in charge must file a written request for a hearing within the ten-day period following the date of the notice. If a request for a hearing is received within the ten-day period, a hearing shall be held within 20 days of receipt of the request. If no request for a hearing is filed within the ten-day period, the suspension of the health certificate is sustained. The regulatory authority may end the suspension at any time if the reasons for the suspension no longer exist. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-19. - Revocation of health certificate. 
(a)  The regulatory authority may, after providing an opportunity for a hearing, revoke a health certificate for serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of this article or for interference with the regulatory authority in the performance of duty. 
(b)  Prior to revocation, the regulatory authority shall notify the holder of the health certificate, or the person in charge, in writing, of the specific reason for which the health certificate is to be revoked at the end of the ten days following service of such notice. An opportunity for a hearing will be provided if a written request for a hearing is filed with the regulatory authority. The holder of the health certificate or the person in charge must file a written request for a hearing within the ten-day period following the date on the notice. If a request for a hearing is received within the ten-day period, a hearing shall be held within 20 days following receipt of the request. If no request for a hearing is filed within the ten-day period, the revocation of the health certificate becomes final. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-20. - Service of notices. 
    A notice provided for in this article is properly served when it is delivered to the holder of the health certificate or the person in charge or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt request, to the last known address of the holder of the health certificate. A copy of the notice shall be filed in the records of the regulatory authority. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-21. - Hearing. 
    The hearings provided for in this article shall be conducted by the regulatory authority at a time and placed designated by the regulatory authority. The city council of the city shall designate an officer, agent or employee of the city as hearing officer for purposes of this section. Any oral testimony given at a hearing shall be recorded and the hearing officer shall make provisions for copying the transcript of such hearing for any person. The appropriate fees shall be assessed to the requesting party as determined by the regulatory authority. The hearing officer shall make final finding based upon the complete hearing record and shall sustain, modify or rescind any notice or order considered in the hearing. A written report of the hearing decision shall be furnished to the holder of the health certificate by the regulatory authority. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-22. - Application after revocation. 
    Whenever a revocation of a health certificate has become final, the holder of the revoked health certificate may make a written application for a new health certificate on forms provided by the regulatory authority. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-23. - Inspection frequency. 
    An inspection of every food establishment within the city shall be performed at least once every six months. Additional inspections of any food establishment shall be performed as often as necessary for the enforcement of this article or of the rules adopted hereby. If, upon the inspection of any food establishment there is found an imminent health hazard which, in the opinion of the city regulatory authority, is a potentially dangerous situation, he shall have authority to order the cessation of operations by the food establishment. The establishment shall have the right to correct the situation and call for a recheck. When the city regulatory authority determines that such situation has been remedied, he may lift the cessation order and perm it the food establishment to resume operations. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-24. - Access. 
    Representatives of the regulatory authority, after providing proper identification, shall be permitted to enter any food establishment at any reasonable time for the purpose of making inspections to determine compliance with this article. The representative shall be permitted to examine the records of the establishment to obtain information pertaining to food and supplies purchased, received or used. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-25. - Report of inspections. 
    Whenever an inspection of a food establishment or a commissary is made, the findings shall be recorded on the inspection report form issued by the state department of health, entitled "Retail Food Establishment Inspection Report", described in the rules adopted hereby and available from the state department of health. The inspection report form shall summarize the requirements of this article and shall set forth a weighted point value for each requirement. Inspection remarks shall be written to reference, by section number, the section of the rules or the article violated and shall state the correction to be made. The rating score of the establishment shall be the total of the weighted point values for all violations, subtracted from 100. A copy of the completed inspection report form shall be furnished to the person in charge of the establishment at the conclusion of the inspection. The completed inspection report form is a public document that shall be made available for public disclosure to any person who requests it according to law. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-26. - Correction of violations. 
(a)  The completed inspection report form shall specify a reasonable period of time for the correction of the violations found. The correction of the violations shall be accomplished within the period specified, in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Priority items (three points). Violations require immediate corrective action not to exceed three days. 
(2)  Priority foundation items (two points). Violations require corrective action within ten days. 
(3)  Core items (one point). Violations require corrective action not to exceed 90 days or next inspection, whichever comes first. 
(b)  Failure to comply with time limits for corrections may result in cessation of food service operations. An opportunity for hearing of the inspection findings or the time limitations or both will be provided if a written request is filed with the regulatory authority within ten days following cessation of operations. The holder of the health certificate or the person in charge must file a written request for hearing within the ten-day period following cessation of the food operations. If a request for hearing is received, a hearing shall be held by the hearing officer within 20 days of receipt of the request. If no request for a hearing is filed within the ten-day period, the cessation of the food operation is sustained. 
(c)  When a food establishment is required under the provision of this section to cease operations, it shall not resume operations until it is shown on recheck that conditions responsible for the order to cease operations no longer exist. Opportunity for recheck shall be offered within a reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-27. - General. 
    Food may be sampled or examined by the regulatory authority as often as necessary for enforcement of this article. The regulatory authority may, upon written notice to the owner or person in charge, specify the reason for the hold order on any food which it believes is in violation of this article. The regulatory authority shall tag, label, or otherwise identify, any food subject to the hold order. No food subject to a hold order shall be used, served or moved from the establishment. The regulatory authority shall permit storage of the food under conditions specified in the hold order, unless storage is not possible without risk to the public health, in which case immediate destruction shall be ordered and accomplished. The hold order shall state that a request for hearing may be filed within ten days and that, if no hearing is requested, the food shall be destroyed. The holder of the health certificate or the person in charge must file a written request for a hearing with the regulatory authority within the ten-day period following the date on the hold order. If a request for hearing is received, a hearing shall be held within 20 days after receipt of the request. On the basis of evidence produced at that hearing, the hold order may be vacated or the owner or person in charge of the food may be directed by written order to denature or destroy such food or to bring it into compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-28. - Submission and review of plans. 
    When a food establishment is constructed or extensively remodeled and when an existing structure is converted to use as a food establishment, properly prepared plans and specifications for such construction, remodeling or conversion shall be submitted to the regulatory authority for review and approval before construction, remodeling or conversion is begun. The plans and specifications shall indicate the proposed layout, arrangement, mechanical plans and construction material of work areas, and the type and model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. The regulatory authority shall approve the plans and specifications if they meet the requirements of this article and of the rules adopted hereby. No food establishment, except a temporary food establishment, shall be constructed, remodeled or converted except in accordance with the plans and specifications approved by the regulatory authority. The regulatory authority shall inspect the food establishment prior to the start of operations to determine compliance with the approved plans and specifications and with the requirements of this article and the rules. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-29. - Procedure when infection suspected. 
    When the regulatory authority has reasonable cause to suspect possible disease transmission by an employee of a food establishment, it may secure a morbidity history of the suspected employee or may make any other investigation as indicated and shall take appropriate action. The regulatory authority may require any or all of the following measures: 
(1)  The immediate exclusion of the employee from employment in the food establishment. 
(2)  The immediate closing of the food establishment concerned until, in the opinion of the regulatory authority, no further danger of disease outbreak exists. 
(3)  Restriction of the employee's services to some area of the establishment where there would be no danger of transmitting the disease. 
(4)  Adequate medical and laboratory examination of the employee and of other employees and of his and their body discharges. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-30. - Classification of establishments. 
    For the purpose of application of minimum construction standards adopted in section 12-31, food establishments are classified as follows: 
(1)  Class 1 establishments shall include cafeterias and full service restaurants. 
(2)  Class 2 establishments shall include fast food establishments, pizza parlors, bakeries, and grocery store delicatessens. 
(3)  Class 3 establishments shall include sandwich shops, ice cream parlors, and convenience stores with hot dogs, etc. 
(4)  Class 4 establishments shall include all other convenience stores and produce stands. 
(5)  Class 5 establishments shall include supermarkets and grocery stores. 
(6)  Class 6 establishments shall include food warehouses and food processing establishments. 
(7)  Class 7 establishments shall include day care facility food preparation areas. 
(8)  Class 8 establishments shall include school cafeterias. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-31. - Minimum construction standards. 
    The minimum construction standards are adopted in addition to the construction requirements of the rules and, to the extent of any conflict with the construction requirements of either, these minimum requirements shall apply.
