Sec. 12-32. - Application of minimum construction standards; effective dates. 
(a)  All new construction of a food establishment classified by section 12-30 shall meet the minimum construction standards of section 12-31 from and after the effective date of this section. 
(b)  Any replacement of facilities or equipment in existing establishments shall, after the effective date of this section, be in accordance with the minimum construction standards adopted in section 12-31. 
(c)  All existing food establishments in the city shall comply with all the minimum construction standards of section 12-31 on or before October 11, 2015. This requirement includes all establishments constructed hereafter or existing as of the effective date of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2264, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 12-33, 12-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ABANDONED AND JUNKED VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017, § 1, adopted Mar. 7, 2007, repealed the former Art. III, §§ 12-35-12-40, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to similar subject matter. For complete derivation see the Code Comparative Table at the end of Volume II. 
Cross reference- Removal and impoundment of vehicles and other property unlawfully on streets, § 19-8. 

Sec. 12-35. - Definitions. 
(a)  For the purposes of this article, a motor vehicle, watercraft, or outboard motor is abandoned if it: 
(1)  Is inoperable, is more than five years old, and has been left unattended on public property for more than 48 hours; 
(2)  Has remained illegally on public property for more than 48 hours; 
(3)  Has remained on private property without the consent of the owner or person in charge of the property for more than 48 hours; 
(4)  Has been left unattended on the right-of-way of a designated county, state, or federal highway for more than 48 hours; or 
(5)  Has been left unattended for more than 24 hours on the right-of-way of a turnpike project constructed and maintained by the Texas Turnpike Authority division of the Texas Department of Transportation or a controlled access highway. 
(b)  A "junked vehicle" is defined as a vehicle that is self-propelled and does not have lawfully attached to it either an unexpired license plate or registration insignia, is: 
(1)  Wrecked, dismantled or partially dismantled, or discarded; or, 
(2)  Inoperable and has remained inoperable for more than 72 consecutive hours if the vehicle is on public property, or 30 consecutive days if the vehicle is on private property. 
(Ord. No. 2017, § 1, 3-7-07; Ord. No. 2313, § 1, 8-15-17) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction generally, § 1-3. 
Sec. 12-36. - Authority to impound; registration. 
(a)  The police department is hereby authorized to take into custody any abandoned motor vehicle, watercraft, or outboard motor found on public or private property. 
(b)  All motor vehicles taken into custody by the police department under this article shall be registered by the department in a record book provided for that purpose. The register must contain a description of the vehicle, the time and place seized, the name of the owner, if known, and the storage and towing charges accrued against the motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2017, § 1, 3-7-07) 
Sec. 12-37. - Notification; hearing and sale. 
(a)  Upon impoundment of an abandoned motor vehicle, watercraft, or outboard motor under this article, the police department shall, not later than the tenth day after taking the item into custody, notify the last known registered owner and all lien holders of record by certified mail. The notice shall: 
(1)  Specify the year, make, model and identification number of the item; 
(2)  Give the location where the item is being held; 
(3)  Inform the owner and lien holders, if any, of the right to claim the item not later than the 20th day after the date of the notice, on payment of all towing, preservation and storage charges, or garagekeeper's charges if applicable; and 
(4)  State that the failure of the owner or lien holder to claim the item within the time provided is a waiver of all right, title, and interest in the item and is consent to the sale of the item at public auction. 
(b)  Notice by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city is sufficient notice under this section if the identity of the last registered owner cannot be determined, the registration has no address for the owner, or the determination with reasonable certainty of the identity and address of all lien holders is impossible. The notice shall be published within the time requirements prescribed for notice by certified mail, and shall contain the information required by subsection (a). Multiple listings of abandoned vehicles may be published in such notice. 
(c)  If an abandoned motor vehicle, watercraft or outboard motor is not reclaimed as provided in subsection (a), the police department may sell the item at public auction or use the item for department purposes. If sold at auction, the purchaser of the item shall take title free and clear of all liens and claims of ownership, shall receive a sales receipt from the police department and is entitled to register the item and receive a certificate of title. The police department shall reimburse itself from the proceeds of the sale for the expenses of the auction and the cost of towing, preserving and storing the item, together with all notice and publication costs incurred. Any excess remaining from the proceeds of such sale shall be held for the owner or lien holder of the item for 90 days, and then shall be deposited in a special fund of the city which shall remain available for the payment of future auction, towing, preserving, and storage fees and all notice and publication costs, whenever the proceeds from a sale of such other abandoned items are insufficient to meet such expenses and costs. 
(Ord. No. 2017, § 1, 3-7-07) 
Sec. 12-38. - Junked vehicle; public nuisance; abatement; exceptions; penalty. 
(a)  Junked vehicles declared to be public nuisance. A junked vehicle or part of a junked vehicle that displays an expired license plate or does not display a license plate, and is visible at any time of the year from a public place or public right-of-way is detrimental to the safety and welfare of the general public, tends to reduce the value of private property, invites vandalism, creates fire hazards, is an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health and safety of minors, produces urban blight adverse to the maintenance and continuing development of the city, and is herein declared a public nuisance. 
(b)  Procedures for abatement. The city manager or his designee is authorized to abate such nuisances under the following procedures. The procedures must be administered by a regularly salaried, full time employee of the city. The person authorized to administer these procedures may enter private property to examine a public nuisance, to obtain information to identify the nuisance, and to remove or direct any person to abate or remove the nuisance. 
(1)  Written notice shall be personally delivered or sent by certified mail with a five-day return requested to the last known registered owner of the nuisance, to each lien holder of record, and to the owner or occupant of the property on which the nuisance is located or, if the nuisance is located on a public right-of-way, the property adjacent to the right-of-way. 
(2)  The notice must be delivered or sent more than ten days prior to the commencement of abatement proceedings. The notice must generally describe the nuisance, state that the nuisance must be abated and removed not later than 10 days after the date of delivery or mailing of the notice, and state that a hearing may be requested prior to the expiration of the ten-day period. If the post office address of the last known registered owner of the nuisance is unknown, notice may be placed on the nuisance or, if the owner is located, personally delivered. If notice is returned undelivered, action to abate the nuisance shall be continued to a date not earlier than the 11th day after the date of the return. 
(3)  Prior to removal of a public nuisance, a public hearing shall be conducted by a municipal judge of the city to determine the existence of a public nuisance and whether the nuisance should be abated and removed. If a property owner to whom notice has been sent requests a hearing, such hearing shall be conducted not earlier than the 11th day after the date of service of the notice. At the hearing, the junked vehicle is presumed, unless demonstrated otherwise, to be inoperable. An order requiring or authorizing the abatement and removal of a nuisance must include the vehicle's description, vehicle identification number, and license plate number, if that information is available at the location of the nuisance. 
(4)  Notice identifying the vehicle or part of the vehicle shall be given to the Texas Department of Public Safety not later than the fifth day after the date of removal. If a vehicle is removed, the vehicle shall not thereafter be reconstructed or made operable. 
(5)  These procedures do not apply to: 
(i)  A vehicle or vehicle part that is completely enclosed in a building in a lawful manner and is not visible from the street or other public or private property; 
(ii)  A vehicle or vehicle part that is stored or parked in a lawful manner on private property in connection with the business of a licensed vehicle dealer or junkyard; or, 
(iii)  An antique or special-interest vehicle stored by a collector on the collector's property, if the vehicle or part and the outdoor storage area are maintained in an orderly manner, not a health hazard, and screened from ordinary public view by appropriate means, including a fence, rapidly growing trees, or shrubbery. 
(6)  The relocation of a junked vehicle that is a public nuisance to another location in the city after a proceeding for the abatement and removal of the public nuisance has commenced has no effect on the proceeding if the junked vehicle constitutes a public nuisance at the new location. 
(7)  The judge of the municipal court of the city may issue orders appropriate or necessary to enforce these procedures. 
(c)  Penalties. A person commits an offense if that person maintains a public nuisance as determined under this article and, on conviction in the municipal court, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed the sum of $200.00 for each offense, and each and every day such offense shall continue shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. On conviction, the court shall order removal and abatement of the nuisance. A person who fails to abate and remove a public nuisance after being ordered to do so by the municipal court shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction in the municipal court, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed the sum of $200.00 for each offense, and each and every day such offense shall continue shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. The abatement and removal procedures authorized herein are in addition to and not in lieu of any remedies, civil or criminal, at law or in equity, to which the city may otherwise be entitled and are cumulative of all other remedies. 
(Ord. No. 2017, § 1, 3-7-07; Ord. No. 2313, § 2, 8-15-17) 
Sec. 12-39. - Disposal; lien. 
(a)  A junked vehicle or junked vehicle part may be removed to a scrap yard or a motor vehicle demolisher. 
(b)  The city shall have a lien on all impounded vehicles, whether or not abandoned, for towing and storage charges as may be established by the city from time to time. 
(c)  The operator of any site authorized by the city to receive impounded vehicles shall maintain duplicate itemized records of the amounts charged for towing, storage, and other costs incurred, and notice of such amounts shall be furnished upon request to the owner and lien holder, if any. 
(Ord. No. 2017, § 1, 3-7-07) 
Secs. 12-40-12-47. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WEEDS AND OTHER VEGETATION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1843, § 1, adopted July 1, 2003, repealed the former Art. IV, §§ 12-48-12-54, and enacted a new Art. IV as set out herein. The former Art. IV pertained to similar subject matter. For complete derivation see the Code Comparative Table at the end of Volume 2. 
Cross reference- Burning of uncut weeds and grass, § 9-2. 

Sec. 12-48. - Growth limitations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning, claiming, occupying or having supervision or control of any real property, occupied or unoccupied, within the corporate limits of the city, to permit weeds, brush or any objectionable or unsightly vegetation to grow to a greater height than 12 inches upon such real property within 150 feet of any property line which abuts street rights-of-way, alleys, utility easements, subdivided additions, developed property or any buildings or other structures. It shall be the duty of such person to keep the area from the line of his property to the curbline next adjacent to it, if there is a curbline, and if not, then to the edge of the pavement, free and clear of the matter referred to above. All vegetation not regularly cultivated and which exceeds 12 inches in height shall be presumed to be objectionable and unsightly, except that regularly cultivated crops shall not be allowed to grow within the right-of-way of any public street or easement but shall be kept mowed the same as provided above. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any person owning, claiming, occupying or having supervision or control of any real property, occupied or unoccupied, within the city, to keep the area adjacent to his property line, including the front or side parkway between the property line or sidewalk and the curb and the rear parkway between the property line and the alley pavement or travel way, or if there is no curb, then to the edge of the pavement, free and clear of the matter referred to herein. Provided, however, that where the alleyway is not open to traffic, that the parkway in such cases shall be deemed to be between the property line and the centerline of the alley. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of any person owning, claiming, occupying or having supervision or control of any real property, occupied or unoccupied, within the city, to keep sidewalk areas and curb lines within and adjacent to such person's property free and clear of grass, weeds and vegetation. 
(Ord. No. 1843, § 1, 7-1-03; Ord. No. 1937, § 1, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 12-49. - Duty to cut and remove. 
    It shall be the duty of any person owning, claiming, occupying or having supervision or control of any real property referred to in section 12-48, to cut and remove all weeds, brush and other objectionable or unsightly vegetation as often as may be necessary to comply with section 12-48, and to use every precaution to prevent the same from growing on such premises. 
(Ord. No. 1843, § 1, 7-1-03) 
Secs. 12-50-12-52. - Reserved. 
Sec. 12-53. - Regulations pertaining to plant life. 
    No plant life of any type shall be planted or maintained so as to be detrimental or dangerous to those owners on adjoining premises or in any way obstruct the view of these persons using public streets and alleys. No screens, hedge, tree, bush or shrub shall be planted or maintained in such position or place so as to be dangerous or detrimental to the health or safety of persons living in any house on the adjoining premises or in any way obstruct the view so as to constitute a traffic hazard. 
(Ord. No. 1843, § 1, 7-1-03) 
See. 12-54. - Specific regulations pertaining to trees. 
    Trees shall be trimmed so as to avoid causing a hazard to public places. The minimum overhang shall be seven feet above sidewalks and above top of street curbs, 14 feet above street surfaces, 14 feet above alley paving if the alley right-of-way is improved, and 14 feet above the grade of the entire alley right-of-way if the alley right-of-way is not improved. The minimum overhang of street curbs may be seven feet when the tree is at least 150 feet from an intersection and not obstructing traffic control signs. No planting of trees or shrubs will be permitted within alley rights-of-way. Growth encroachments in an alley shall not exceed one foot. In areas where the dedicated right-of-way is enhanced by alley easements on either or both sides, the one-foot maximum growth encroachment shall also be effective. 
    It shall be the duty of any person owning, claiming, occupying or having supervision or control of any real property, occupied or unoccupied, within the corporate and territorial limits of the city, to keep the area adjacent to his property line, including the front or side parkway between the property line or sidewalk and the curb and the rear parkway between the property line and the alley pavement or travel way, or if there is no curb, then to the edge of the pavement, free and clear of the matter referred to in this section. Provided, however, that where the alleyway is not open to traffic, that the parkway in such cases shall be deemed to be between the property line and the centerline of the alley. 
(Ord. No. 1843, § 1, 7-1-03) 
Sec. 12-55. - Duty to cut and remove. 
    Upon a determination by the city and notice from the building official or his designee, it shall be the duty of any person owning, claiming, occupying or having supervision or control of any real property referred to in section 12-54, to cut, trim and/or remove any tree or parts of a tree determined to be dead, diseased, or damaged beyond the point of recovery, or in danger of falling. 
(Ord. No. 1843, § 1, 7-1-03) 
Sec. 12-56. - Notice to comply with article; work done by city if notice not complied with. 
(a)  In the event that any person owning, claiming or occupying or having supervision or control of any real property, occupied or unoccupied, within the corporate limits of the city, fails to comply with the provisions of this article, it shall be the duty of the city manager or his designee to give seven days' notice in writing to such person or persons: 
(1)  Personally to the owner in writing; 
(2)  By letter addressed to the owner at the owner's address as recorded in the appraisal district records of Dallas County; or 
(3)  If personal service cannot be obtained: 
a.  By publication at least once; 
b.  By posting the notice on or near the front door of each building on the property to which the violation relates; or 
c.  By posting the notice on a placard attached to a stake driven into the ground on the property to which the violation relates, if the property contains no buildings. 
(b)  Similar notice shall be given to any person occupying or having supervision or control of the property as an occupant, tenant, or lessee. 
(c)  If the notice to the property owner is mailed by the United States Postal Service, certified mail, and the notice is returned as "refused" or "unclaimed", the validity of the notice is not affected, and the notice is considered as delivered. 
(d)  The city, in the notice of the violation, may inform the owner, occupant or person having supervision or control over the property, by regular mail and a posting on the property, that if the owner commits another violation of the same kind or nature that poses a danger to the public health and safety on or before the first anniversary of the date of the notice, the city without further notice may correct the violation at the owner's expense and assess the expense against the property. If a violation covered by a notice under this subsection occurs within the one-year period, and the city has not been informed in writing by the owner of an ownership change, then the city without notice may take any action permitted by this section and assess its expenses as provided in section 12-57. 
(Ord. No. 1843, § 1, 7-1-03) 
Sec. 12-57. - Collection of expenses incurred by city under article. 
    The expense incurred by the city pursuant to section 12-56 correcting the condition of such property, and the cost of publishing notice in the newspaper, shall be paid by the city and charged to the owner of such property. In the event the owner fails or refuses to pay such expense, the city shall file with the County Clerk of Dallas County a statement of the expenses incurred in correcting the condition of the property. When such statement is filed, the city shall have a privileged lien on such property, second only to tax liens and liens for such improvements, to secure the payment of the amount so expended. Such amount shall bear interest at the rate of ten percent per annum from the date the city incurs the expense. For any such expenditures and interest, suit may be instituted and recovery and foreclosure had by the city. The statement of expense filed with the county clerk or a certified copy thereof shall be prima facie proof of the amount expended in such work, improvement or correction of the property. 
(Ord. No. 1843, § 1, 7-1-03) 
Sec. 12-58. - Penalty for violations of article. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine, upon conviction in the municipal court, of not more than $500.00, and each and every day the premises shall remain in a condition in violation of the terms of this article shall constitute a separate offense. This section shall be in addition to and cumulative of the provisions for the abatement of the nuisance by the city and charging the cost of same against the owner of the premises. 
(Ord. No. 1843, § 1, 7-1-03) 
Secs. 12-59-12-62. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES ON PREMISES OF DRIVE-IN RESTAURANT 

Sec. 12-63. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this article, a "drive-in restaurant" shall be deemed to be any restaurant where meals, sandwiches, cold drinks, beverages, ice cream or other food is served directly to or is permitted to be consumed by patrons in automobiles, motorcycles or other vehicles parked on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 383, § 1, 10-24-66) 
Sec. 12-64. - Enumerated. 
    The following acts of conduct of any person entering any drive-in restaurant premises are hereby declared to be unlawful and any person found guilty of any such acts shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(1)  To park any motor vehicle on the premises and leave the premises without getting the consent of the owner or operator of such restaurant. Any vehicle parked upon the premises of any drive-in restaurant unattended or unoccupied for a period of one hour or more shall be presumed to have been parked without the permission of the owner or operator of such drive-in restaurant, in which event such vehicle may be towed by the drive-in restaurant operator. 
(2)  No person shall drive any vehicle on the premises in any race, speed competition or contest, drag race or acceleration contest, test of physical endurance, exhibition of speed or acceleration, or for the purpose of making a speed record, and no person shall in any manner participate in any such race, competition, contest, test, or exhibition. 
(3)  No person shall drive any motor vehicle in or through the premises for purposes of making either a right or left turn to a street or highway. 
Sec. 12-65. - Premises declared public place. 
    For the purpose of preserving public peace, health and safety, the entire premises occupied by a drive-in restaurant, together with means of ingress thereto and egress therefrom, are hereby declared to be a public place. 
(Ord. No. 383, § 2, 10-24-66) 
Sec. 12-66. - Sign advising of article provisions. 
    It shall be the duty of the drive-in restaurant operator to post on the premises in a conspicuous location one or more signs bearing the following legend: 
    "No unoccupied vehicle may be left on these premises without the consent of the restaurant operator. Any vehicle left on these premises unoccupied for one hour or more will be towed if it is not removed." 
Secs. 12-67-12-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - WRECKER SERVICE 

Sec. 12-71. - Definition. 
    For purposes of this article, the term "wrecker" means a motor vehicle designed to be used primarily for moving wrecked or disabled motor vehicles by towing or use of a dolly or any other device upon any public street or highway within the City of Duncanville. 
(Ord. No. 1140, § 2, 11-16-87) 
Sec. 12-72. - Identification. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to operate a wrecker upon the public streets and highways of the city without said wrecker having displayed on the outside of both sides of the wrecker the name, address and telephone number of the wrecker company or operator and in accordance with any rules adopted by the Texas Department of Labor and Standards. 
(Ord. No. 1140, § 2, 11-16-87) 
Secs. 12-73-12-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES ON SHOPPING CENTER PROPERTY 

Sec. 12-81. - Speed limit; parking signs. 
(a)  When signs have been posted upon shopping center property, no person shall operate or drive any vehicle upon any shopping center property at a greater speed than 20 miles per hour and any speed in excess of said limits shall be prima facie evidence that such speed is not reasonable nor prudent under the circumstances then existing having regard to the actual and potential hazards and is unlawful. 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic-control device, on a sidewalk or on any part of the sidewalk area. 
Sec. 12-82. - Scope of article. 
    Shopping centers which avail themselves of the provisions of this article shall, be deemed to be public places for purposes of this article only. 
Sec. 12-83. - Enforcement of article options; written request required. 
    The provisions of this article shall not become effective unless and until the owners of such shopping centers file a request in writing with the traffic engineer requesting that the provisions of this article be enforced on such shopping center property. Representatives of the shopping center shall post and erect all necessary signs upon the shopping center property to give notice of the provisions of this article and receive written verification from the traffic engineer approving the center's traffic-control plan. 
Secs. 12-84-12-87. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII-A. - REGULATION OF NUISANCES-NONRESIDENTIAL 

Sec. 12-88. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Accessory use shall mean a use customarily incidental to the main use and must be located on the same lot as the main use. 
    Front yard shall mean all areas between the front face of the building and the front property line. See figures 1, 2 and 3 of this article. 
    Nonresidential property shall mean any property not zoned or used for single family, duplex or apartment purposes. 
    Open storage shall mean the outside placement of any article, except a permitted vehicle, in excess of 24 hours. 
    Person in charge or control of premises shall mean a person or firm, whether owner, lessee, tenant, occupant, or otherwise, who has possession, occupancy, direction or management of the premises. 
    Truck shall mean any motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the transportation of property, and which has a rated capacity in excess of one and one-half tons according to the manufacturer's classification. 
    Trailer shall mean any vehicle designed or intended to be pulled or moved by a motor vehicle. 
    Truck-tractor shall mean any motor vehicle designed or used primarily for drawing other vehicles. 
    Vacant nonresidential property shall mean any lot not containing a structure. 
    Vehicle shall mean every device, motorized or nonmotorized, the licensing or registration of which is required by the laws of Texas or any other state or country, in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway. 
Cross reference- Rules of construction generally, § 1-3. 
Sec. 12-89. - Nuisance, open storage. 
    The following conditions shall constitute public nuisances, the keeping, permitting, or maintenance of which by any person in charge or control of the premises shall be unlawful, and which shall be abated as provided in section 12-90: 
(1)  The keeping or depositing on or the scattering over such premises of junk, trash, or debris, or abandoned, discarded or unused objects or equipment. This includes, but is not limited to, furniture, stoves, refrigerators, freezers, appliances, cans, containers, or unused, discarded and/or inoperable motor vehicles; or any item which is not customarily used or stored outside, or which is not made of material that is resistant to damage or deterioration from exposure to the outside environment, for a period in excess of 24 hours. (Additional requirements relating to open storage on nonresidential property are specified by individual zoning district in the city's zoning ordinance.) 
(2)  Except on properties zoned "I" (Industrial), "I-l" (Light Industrial) or "I-2", (Heavy Industrial), no person in charge or control shall keep a tractor, truck, bus, or any vehicle having a rated capacity in excess of one and one-half tons according to manufacturer's specifications or permit the same to be parked, left or placed on nonresidential property, including in driveways, for other than the supervised loading or unloading of goods or passengers, and delivery vehicles owned by a business and parked on that business property when parked in such a manner that is not in violation of any other city ordinance. 
(3)  Open storage of objects being used by the ongoing business on the premises shall be permitted in areas zoned "C" (Commercial), "C-l" (Light Commercial), "C-2" (Heavy Commercial), "I" (Industrial), "I-l" (Light Industrial) and "I-2" (Heavy Industrial). Such open storage is not permitted in the front yard of any nonresidential property or in the side yard adjacent to a street on a corner lot. 
(4)  The area occupied by a permitted motor vehicle shall not be considered when calculating the area occupied by open storage. 
(5)  Open storage is not permitted on any vacant nonresidential lot. 
(6)  Dirt, rock, debris, etc. to be used as fill material shall not be stored on nonresidential property longer than 30 days, unless it is part of a construction project for which the city has issued a permit. 
Sec. 12-90. - Nuisance; abatement. 
(a)  Notice of a violation of this article shall be given to the owner of the property in the manner required by section 12-56 of this Code. 
(b)  If the owner of the property does not comply with the notice and correct the violation within seven days, the city may do the work or make the improvements required and pay for the work done or improvements made and charge the expenses to the owner of the property. 
(c)  To obtain a lien against the property, the city manager or his designee must file a statement of expenses with the County Clerk of Dallas County. The lien statement must state the name of the owner, if known, and the legal description of the property. The lien attaches upon the filing of the lien statement with the county clerk. The lien obtained by the city is security for the expenditures made and interest accruing at the rate of ten percent on the amount due from the date of payment by the city. The lien is inferior only to tax liens and for liens for street improvements. 
(Ord. No. 1662, § 2, 7-18-00; Ord. No. 2013, § 1, 2-6-07)

ARTICLE VIII-B. - REGULATION OF NUISANCES-RESIDENTIAL 

Sec. 12-91. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following words and phrases have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Accessory use shall mean a use customarily incidental to the main use and must be located on the same lot as the main use. 
    Boat trailer shall mean a trailer that is designed and intended to be used for, and whose sole purpose is, the transportation of a boat or watercraft. 
    Front yard shall mean all areas between the front face(s) of the building and the front property line. See figures 1, 2, 3, and 4 of this article. 
    Open storage shall mean the outside placement of any article for a continuous period in excess of 24 hours, other than those objects described in section 12-92(3). 
    Permitted vehicle shall mean any vehicle other than: 
(1)  A junked vehicle as defined in Article III of Chapter 12 of the Duncanville Code of Ordinances, or 
(2)  A tractor, truck, bus or any vehicle having a rated capacity in excess of one and one-half tons according to the manufacturer's specifications. 
    Person in charge or control of premises shall mean a person or firm, whether owner, lessee, tenant, occupant, or otherwise, who has possession, occupancy, direction or management of the premises. 
    Residential property shall mean any property zoned or used for single-family, duplex or apartment purposes. 
    Trailer shall mean any vehicle designed or intended to be pulled or moved. 
    Truck shall mean any motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the transportation of property, and which has a rated capacity in excess of one and one-half tons according to the manufacturer's specifications. 
    Truck-tractor shall mean any motor vehicle designed or used primarily for drawing other vehicles. 
    Vacant residential property shall mean any residential lot not containing a structure. 
    Vehicle shall mean every device, motorized or nonmotorized, the licensing or registration of which is required by the laws of Texas or any other state or country, in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway. 
(Ord. No. 1834, § 1, 3-18-03) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction generally, § 1-3. 
Sec. 12-92. - Nuisance; open storage. 
    The following conditions shall constitute public nuisances, the keeping, permitting, or maintenance of which by any person in charge or control of the premises shall be unlawful, and which shall be abated as provided in section 12-93: 
(1)  The keeping or depositing on or the scattering over such premises of junk, trash, or debris, or abandoned, discarded or unused objects or equipment. This includes, but is not limited to, furniture, stoves, refrigerators, freezers, appliances, cans, containers, or unused, discarded and/or inoperable motor vehicles; or any item which is not customarily used or stored outside on property used for residential purposes, or which is not made of a material that is resistant to damage or deterioration from exposure to the outside environment, for a period in excess of 24 hours. 
(2)  No tractor, truck, bus, or any vehicle having a rated capacity in excess of one and one-half tons according to manufacturer's specifications shall be kept, parked, left or placed on residential property, including in driveways, for other than the supervised loading or unloading of goods or passengers. 
(3)  Open storage is not permitted in the front yard or on the front porch of a residential building or in any side yard abutting a public street or alley. Articles which may be kept in such front or side yards include, but are not limited to: 
a.  Landscaping, ornamental structures, bird baths, plant containers, statues, one barbecue grill or smoker, or lawn furniture made of material that is resistant to damage or deterioration from exposure to the outside elements. 
b.  Permitted vehicles. 
c.  A motorized home or recreational vehicle, when parked on an approved surface as determined by the building official. 
d.  A camper trailer or boat trailer (with boat) when such trailer cannot be parked behind the front yard because of inadequate side yard or alley access, when parked on an approved surface as determined by the building official. Property that adjoins a platted alley shall be deemed to have adequate alley access for the purposes of this section. 
e.  No trailers other than boat trailers (with boat) or camper trailers are permitted in a front yard, whether or not parked on an improved surface. All vehicles, trailers and boats, the keeping or storage of which is permitted by this article or other city ordinances, must display proof of a current license or registration. 
f.  Temporary outdoor storage containers may be used and located in the front and/or side yards of residences only under the conditions specified herein. A portable, weather-resistant container used for the temporary storage or shipment of household goods and items, incidental to the residential use of the premises, may be located on residential property for periods not to exceed 15 days and for no more than two times in any consecutive 12-month period. No more than one such container may be situated on any lot, only upon issuance of a permit by the building official. Such permit must be prominently displayed on the container at all times, which shall show the expiration date of the permit. Containers shall not be larger than eight feet by 16 feet and no taller than eight feet. No container may be located within or encroach upon an alley, street or utility easement or public right-of-way. No part of a container shall be located within three feet of the primary dwelling. Containers shall be placed entirely on a paved surface, unless otherwise authorized by the building official. Containers shall be secured and locked when unattended and the container and its immediate area shall be kept free and clear of trash and debris at all times. The building official may, upon cause shown, grant extensions to the frequency or duration of the permit authorized herein and may suspend or revoke a permit for noncompliance with the terms hereof. Appeals from the denial, revocation or suspension of a permit shall be made to the city council and the decision of the council shall be final. 
(4)  No person in charge or control of residential premises shall use more than five percent of the lot area of such premises for open storage; no open storage is permitted which otherwise constitutes a nuisance or other violation of law. The area occupied by a permitted operable motor vehicle with valid state registration shall not be considered when calculating the area occupied by open storage. 
(5)  Open storage is not permitted on any vacant residential lot. 
(6)  Dirt, rock, debris, etc. to be used as fill material shall not be stored on residential property longer than 30 days, unless it is part of a construction project for which the city has issued a permit. 
(Ord. No. 1834, § 2, 3-18-03; Ord. No. 1955, § 1, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 12-93. - Nuisance; abatement. 
(a)  Notice of a violation of this article shall be given to the owner of the property in the manner required by section 12-56 of this Code. 
(b)  If the owner of the property does not comply with the notice and correct the violation within seven days, the city may do the work or make the improvements required and pay for the work done or improvements made and charge the expenses to the owner of the property. 
(c)  To obtain a lien against the property, the city manager or his designee must file a statement of expenses with the County Clerk of Dallas County. The lien statement must state the name of the owner, if known, and the legal description of the property. The lien attaches upon the filing of the lien statement with the county clerk. The lien obtained by the city is security for the expenditures made and interest accruing at the rate of ten percent per annum on the amount due from the date of payment by the city. The lien is inferior only to tax liens and for liens for street improvements. 
(Ord. No. 1662, § 3, 7-18-00; Ord. No. 1834, § 3, 3-18-03; Ord. No. 2013, § 2, 2-6-07)
