If the permittee, owner, manager, occupant, agent or person having beneficial use of the property or structure(s) upon which such sign is mounted or located fails to remove or repair the sign within ten days after such notice, such sign may be removed by order of the building official at the expense of the permittee, owner, manager, occupant, agent or person having beneficial use of the property upon which it is located. The building official may cause any sign which is an immediate hazard to persons to be removed summarily and without notice. All expenses incurred by the city incidental to such removal may be placed as a lien against the property from which the sign is removed. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-18. - Removal of obsolete signs. 
(a)  Any sign declared by the building official to be an obsolete sign shall be removed by the owner, manager, occupant, agent or person having beneficial use of the property or structure(s) upon which such sign is erected. Removal shall be effected within ten days of the date of written notification to do so from the building official. 
(b)  Upon failure to comply with such notice, the building official is hereby authorized to cause the removal of such sign, and any expense incidental thereto shall be paid by the owner, manager, occupant, agent or person having beneficial use of the property or structure(s) upon which such sign is mounted or located. All expenses incurred by the city incidental to such removal may be placed as a lien against the property from which the sign is removed. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
ARTICLE VI. - SIGN PLACEMENT 

Sec. 16A-19. - Exceptions to setback requirements. 
(a)  The building official may approve temporary exceptions to setback requirements if the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The existing street right-of-way is greater than necessary to accommodate current pavement width but will be necessary to meet future roadway design requirements; and 
(2)  Traffic visibility shall not be obstructed; and 
(3)  The sign shall be located entirely on private property. 
(4)  The person or organization granted the exception must in writing acknowledge understanding that: 
a.  The building official may issue notice requiring compliance with current ordinances within 90 days of the date of such notice; and 
b.  All expenses incurred in achieving compliance shall be borne by the person or organization responsible for achieving such compliance; and 
c.  In the event that this notice is not complied with, the city may enter the property, cause the removal of the sign, and place a lien against the property for all expenses incurred by the city. 
(b)  The building official may require a setback greater than those specified in this chapter when the building official determines that such is necessary to provide adequate visibility or safety for vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-20. - Sign use on public property. 
(a)  Notwithstanding other requirements of this chapter, the city manager may approve the placement of decorative civic flags or banners or minor signs on public property on a temporary basis, for the following purposes: 
(1)  Seasonal events. 
(2)  Special occasions. 
(3)  Civic or community projects, celebrations or events sponsored or co-sponsored by the City of Duncanville, the Duncanville Independent School District, or the Duncanville Chamber of Commerce. 
(b)  Such approval shall not constitute any type of permanent right, easement or license for the use of public property. 
(c)  The city may install decorative civic flags or banners on a year-round basis on public property or right-of-way when attached to permanent or other structural members or supports, including, but not limited to, electric light poles. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-21. - Legal nonconforming signs. 
(a)  Legal nonconforming signs may be maintained as erected, however such signs must be brought into compliance with current rules, requirements, regulations and ordinances whenever: 
(1)  The sign is altered, or 
(2)  The sign is destroyed or damaged such that the cost to repair the sign is equal to or greater than 50 percent of its replacement cost, or 
(3)  The property remains vacant or without a current certificate of occupancy issued by the city for a period of six months or longer. 
(b)  If the only alteration to a legal nonconforming sign consists of refacing, the sign may be otherwise maintained as erected. 
(c)  Existing legal nonconforming off-premise billboard signs may be altered by conversion to digital billboards as specified in section 16A-22(c)(2)b and c. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04; Ord. No. 2136, § 2, 3-15-11) 
ARTICLE VII. - PROHIBITIONS 

Sec. 16A-22. - Prohibited signs and activities. 
(a)  Signs not otherwise described . Any sign, placement or use of a sign not specifically described or allowed by this chapter is prohibited. 
(b)  Safety and traffic . 
(1)  Any sign erected in a manner that would confuse or obstruct the view or interpretation of any official traffic sign, signal or device is prohibited. 
(2)  No sign shall be erected or material distributed in such a manner as to constitute a public hazard, menace or danger. 
(3)  No sign may be erected within the visibility triangle when determined by the city's traffic engineer or the building official to constitute a traffic hazard. 
(c)  Certain illuminated signs prohibited. 
(1)  No sign shall be illuminated to such an intensity or in such a manner as to constitute a traffic hazard. 
(2)  Moving, flashing, animated, intermittently lighted, changing color, revolving or similarly constructed signs, beacons, jump clocks or digital devices showing pricing information, the time, temperature and similar data are prohibited. 
Exceptions: 
a.  Scoreboards. 
b.  Signs with changeable electronic messages or images as permitted and approved by the building official. 
1.  The message or image displayed in such signs shall not change more often than once in every eight seconds. All message changes shall be completed within two seconds, and must occur simultaneously on the entire sign face. 
2.  Moving, animated, flashing, intermittent, scrolling or streaming messages or images shall not be permitted, nor may changeable electronic signs consist of a static image projected upon a stationary object. 
c.  Existing legal nonconforming off-premise billboard signs, as defined herein, may be converted to digital billboards subject to the restrictions for changeable electronic messages or images shown in section 16A-22(c)(2)b. above, subject to: 
1.  No portion of such sign shall be closer than five feet from the right-of-way line of a controlled access freeway. 
2.  A minimum linear spacing of 1,500 feet, as measured from the display surface, shall be required between one digital billboard and any other digital billboard on the same side of the roadway. 
3.  A digital billboard shall incorporate systems/devices that will automatically freeze the sign in one position if a malfunction or damage occurs and adjust the brightness/intensity of the display according to ambient natural light conditions. 
4.  The owner and/or lessee of a digital billboard shall coordinate with the city to display emergency information critical to the traveling public, such as AMBER ALERTS from a National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC) authorized source, and other alerts involving terrorist attacks, natural disasters. Emergency messages are to remain in the display's rotation according to the designated issuing agency's protocols. 
5.  If the city determines that a digital billboard causes glare or otherwise impairs the vision of the driver of a motor vehicle or otherwise interferes with the operation of a motor vehicle, the owner or its lessee of the sign, within 12 hours of a request by the city, shall reduce the intensity of the display to a level specified by this Code, or to an alternative setting that satisfactorily mitigates the specific impairment to the driver as determined by the city. 
6.  The owner or its lessee of a digital billboard shall provide the city contact information for a person who is available to be contacted at any time and who is able to turn off the display promptly should a billboard malfunction or damage occur. 
7.  A digital billboard or its message, content and/or image shall not be configured to resemble a warning or danger signal or cause a driver to mistake the digital billboard or its message, content and/or image for a warning or danger signal. 
8.  A digital billboard or its message, content and/or image shall not resemble or simulate any lights or official signage used to control traffic in accordance with the currently adopted edition of the TXDOT Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
9.  The conversion of existing legal nonconforming off-premise billboard signs to digital billboards shall only be allowed for billboards adjoining Interstate Highway 20 or U.S. Highway 67. 
10.  All requests for permits for the conversion of an existing conventional billboard to a digital billboard shall be processed in the following sequential manner: 
i.  If the applicant satisfies the requirements of this section, the city will issue a preliminary permit granting permission for the digital billboard, subject to the granting of a permit by the Texas Department of Transportation, where applicable. 
ii.  The applicant shall obtain a permit from the Texas Department of Transportation allowing the requested conversion, and shall present a true copy of that permit to the city, not later than 12 months following the issuance of the preliminary permit. The preliminary permit shall expire 12 months after its issuance, without further action from the city, if no final sign permit has been issued in that time. 
iii.  If the applicant and the Texas Department of Transportation permit satisfy the requirements of this section, the city shall issue a final sign permit for the digital billboard. 
iv.  The preliminary permit shall expire 12 months after its issuance, without further action by the city, if no sign permit has been issued in that time. 
d.  One blinking or intermittently lighted "open-type" window sign may be displayed. 
1.  The area of such signs shall not exceed 3.25 square feet. 
2.  Such signs remain subject to all other requirements of this chapter, including section 16A-38. 
(3)  No portion of an illuminated sign shall have luminescence greater than 200 foot lamberts. 
(4)  No illuminated sign shall be erected within 150 feet of a residential district unless the lighting is shielded from view of the residential district. 
(d)  Off-premise signs. 
(1)  Except as specified in this chapter, all off-premise signs are prohibited. This includes all signs commonly referred to as billboards, except those which have been converted to digital billboards as specified in section 16A-22(c)(2)c. 
(2)  Where more than one business occupies the same property, no signage other than multi-use signs may be erected or displayed on any part of the property not occupied by the business erecting or displaying such sign. 
(e)  Usage or content of signs. 
(1)  Signs that display any obscene, indecent, suggestive or immoral matter as determined by the building official are prohibited. Decisions of the building official regarding that which constitutes such matter may be appealed to the sign control board. 
(2)  The use of any actual goods, wares, merchandise, vehicles or articles for sale or display as a sign or part of a sign is prohibited. 
(3)  Signs offering property or space for sale, rent or lease are prohibited when at least 80 percent of such property or space is occupied. 
(4)  No minor sign, banner or any other sign defined in this chapter or designated by the building official as a temporary sign shall be used or permitted for use as a permanent sign. No such sign may be displayed longer than 90 days unless a legally permitted permanent sign is also displayed at the location at which the temporary sign is displayed. 
(f)  Miscellaneous prohibitions. 
(1)  Except as specified in this chapter, no sign, name, number or advertising material other than building addresses may be applied to, placed or scattered upon streets, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, trees, rocks, natural features, fences, railings, public telephones, utility poles or any public property. Any sign found on public property or right-of-way may be seized. Removal and disposal of same are hereby authorized. 
(2)  No signage other than the main permitted signs shall be painted on or attached to the poles or support members of any sign. 
(3)  No business may erect, maintain or display a sign unless a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the City of Duncanville, application for same has been received by the city, a building permit has been issued for construction of the business requesting the sign, or an agreement to rent, lease or buy a structure has been finalized by the business requesting the sign. 
(4)  No sign may be painted, mounted, erected, maintained or displayed on the roof of a structure, or in such a manner as to extend above the walls of a structure. However, as an exception, wall signs may be attached to a mansard roof, provided that such signs do not extend above the top of the roof. 
(5)  No portable sign shall be permitted. 
(6)  No signs of any type are permitted on the rear wall of any structure. 
Exceptions: 
a.  One wall sign which displays the name and telephone number of the business may be displayed on the rear wall of a business located on a property adjacent to the right-of-way of Interstate Highway 20 or US Highway 67. 
b.  One wall sign used as a menu board may be displayed on the rear wall of a structure. 
(7)  No sign may have more than two faces. The faces of a double-faced sign may not be separated by an angle greater than 45 degrees. 
(8)  No sign other than a banner, flag or pennant may be constructed of fabric or nonrigid material. 
Exception: Flexible faces may be installed subject to the following requirements: 
1.  Generally. 
a.  Flexible faces may be installed on cabinet-type signs only. 
b.  Material used for flexible faces shall weigh no less than 16 ounces per square yard. 
c.  Flexible faces shall be constructed of noncombustible materials, except that such faces may be made of slow-burning materials if supported by noncombustible materials only. 
2.  Mounting of flexible faces. 
a.  Flexible faces shall be mounted securely in a sign cabinet by a system specified or recommended by the manufacturer of the flexible face and approved by the building official. 
b.  Flexible faces shall not be secured to the cabinet by screws, nails or other fasteners or methods that penetrate or tear the flexible face, except as specified or recommended by the manufacturer and approved by the building official. 
3.  Permitting and inspection. 
a.  All signs with flexible faces are subject to inspection by the building official prior to erection to ensure that the requirements of all applicable ordinances, statutes, laws or codes have been met. 
b.  No permit shall be issued until the applicant has provided the building official with documentation showing the weight of the flexible face and details of the mounting system. 
(9)  Signs shall not project from any surface of a vehicle. 
(10)  It shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle displaying signage to be parked, left or stood within 50 feet of the right-of-way of any street, highway or public way, such that it advertises the business named on the vehicle, except for the purpose of supervised transportation, loading or unloading of passengers or goods, or under specific conditions as determined by the building official. 
(11)  No inflatable sign shall be permitted except as may be hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04; Ord. No. 1978, § 5, 4-4-06; Ord. No. 2106, §§ 3, 4, 2-16-10; Ord. No. 2136, § 2, 3-15-11; Ord. No. 2173, § 2, 4-17-12) 
ARTICLE VIII. - RULES FOR SPECIFIC SIGN TYPES 

Sec. 16A-23. - Banners. 
(a)  Allowed uses: Unrestricted. 
Exception: May be not used as real estate signs except in areas zoned "Industrial", "Light Industrial" or "Heavy Industrial". 
(b)  Permit: Required for each banner visible from the outside of a structure. 
(c)  Maximum height: Not applicable. 
(d)  Maximum area: Forty square feet. 
(e)  Placement: 
(1)  Shall only be displayed by attachment to exterior walls of the building occupied by the business applying for the permit. 
(f)  Maximum number: Two per business address, however, each banner must be placed on a separate wall or structure. 
Exception: 
(1)  No more than one banner may be displayed on any single wall of a business. 
(2)  Vehicle repair facilities may also display one banner per bay door. 
(g)  Duration: 
(1)  Grand opening: maximum use period of two weeks within 90 days of certificate of occupancy issuance. 
(2)  Other allowed uses: 30-day permit, with a maximum of three permits within a calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04; Ord. No. 1978, § 6, 4-4-06; Ord. No. 2173, § 3, 4-17-12; Ord. No. 2281, § 1, 8-16-16) 
Sec. 16A-23.5. - Banners; vehicle repair facilities. 
(a)  Allowed uses: Unrestricted. 
Exception: May not be used as real estate signs except in areas zoned "Industrial", "Light Industrial" or "Heavy Industrial". 
(b)  Permit: Required for each banner on exterior wall surfaces or structures or visible from the outside of a structure when bay doors are open and when banner is within ten feet of bay door opening. 
(c)  Maximum height: Not applicable. 
(d)  Maximum area: 
(1)  Thirty square feet when mounted in or visible through bay doors. 
(2)  Other banners: Forty square feet. 
(e)  Placement: 
(1)  Banners within ten feet of bay doors must be secured such that banner will remain stable and will not move excessively in a moderate wind. 
(2)  Other banners must be secured by all corners to building or supporting member(s), or banner must be mounted in a framework approved by the building official. 
(f)  Maximum number: Two per business address on exterior walls or structures. No more than one banner may be displayed on any single exterior wall or structure of a vehicle repair facility. 
Exception: Vehicle repair facilities may also display one banner in each bay door. 
(g)  Duration: 
(1)  Grand opening: maximum use period of two weeks within 90 days of certificate of occupancy issuance. 
(2)  In bay doors: Maximum use period of 12 months per calendar year. 
(3)  Other banners: 30-day permit, not to exceed six permits issued consecutively, with a maximum of twelve permits per calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 1978, § 7, 4-4-06; Ord. No. 2173, § 4, 4-17-12) 
Sec. 16A-24. - Changeable advertisement. 
(a)  Allowed uses: 
(1)  Service stations/convenience stores. 
(2)  Restaurants. 
(b)  Permit: Required. 
(c)  Maximum height: Eight feet. 
(d)  Maximum area: Eight square feet. 
(e)  Placement: 
(1)  Frame must be securely mounted to wall or other permanent structure. 
(2)  No changeable advertisement may be erected less than ten feet from any other changeable advertisement. 
(3)  A changeable advertisement mounted on a pole other than a supporting member of a canopy shall be considered to be a pole sign and shall be subject to the regulations governing pole signs. 
(f)  Maximum number: Six per structure; maximum of ten per property. 
Exception: Service stations may also erect one sign above each gas pump. 
(g)  Duration: Permanent. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04; Ord. No. 1978, § 8, 4-4-06) 
Sec. 16A-25. - Development directional signs. 
(a)  Allowed uses: Traffic direction to new residential development. 
(b)  Permit required. Upon the issuance of a permit the applicant will receive a permit label that shall be affixed to the front of each sign. Any directional sign displayed on city right-of-way without a permit label will be removed and disposed of. 
(c)  Maximum height: Three feet. 
(d)  Maximum area: Six square feet. 
(e)  Placement: 
(1)  No part of sign may be closer than one foot from back of curb or edge of sidewalk. 
(2)  May not be placed in medians. 
(f)  Maximum number: Not applicable. 
(g)  Duration: May not be displayed before 12:00 noon on Friday and must be removed by 12:00 noon on the following Monday. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-26. - Flags. 
(a)  Allowed uses: 
(1)  Governmental. 
(2)  Civic. 
(b)  Permit: Not required. 
(c)  Maximum height of flagpole: Fifty feet. 
(d)  Maximum area of flag: Not applicable. 
(e)  Placement: 
(1)  Fifteen foot setback. 
(2)  Roof-mounted flags are prohibited. 
(3)  Flags erected on private property shall not protrude over public property. 
(4)  On business property, flags shall not be erected less than 500 feet from residentially-zoned property. 
(f)  Maximum number: 
(1)  Flags of governmental entities: Three flags per property. 
(2)  Flags of civic entities: One per property. 
(g)  Duration : Permanent. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-27. - Ground signs. 
(a)  Allowed uses: 
(1)  Real estate. 
(2)  "Coming Soon" signs. 
(3)  Commercial or residential development. 
(b)  Permit : Not required. 
(c)  Maximum height: Fifteen feet. 
(d)  Maximum Area: Thirty-two square feet. 
Exception: Model home or traffic directional, eight square feet. 
(e)  Placement: 
(1)  Fifteen-foot front setback. 
Exception: Model homes, ten feet from city property line. 
(2)  Ground signs may not be attached to the ground for the purpose of use as a permanent sign. 
(f)  Maximum number: One per property. 
(g)  Duration: Sign shall be removed when the property is sold, rented, leased or fully developed. 
Exception: "Coming Soon", duration of active building permit or until business opens. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-28. - Handbills. 
(a)  Allowed uses: Unrestricted. 
(b)  Permit: Any person distributing handbills shall first register with the building official and obtain a permit. Permits will be issued on an annual, weekly or daily basis, unless revoked earlier. A registration fee as well as a permit fee shall be paid to the city prior to a permit being issued. 
(c)  Maximum height: Not applicable. 
(d)  Maximum area: Not applicable. 
(e)  Placement: It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute handbills in or on any occupied private property unless: 
(1)  Such handbill is handed directly to an occupant of the property who is willing to accept it, or 
(2)  Such handbill is attached securely to or upon the premises. 
(f)  Maximum number: Not applicable. 
(g)  Duration: Annual, weekly or daily as permitted. 
(h)  Other requirements: 
(1)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the distribution of current newspapers or periodicals intended for public sale or subscription. 
(2)  This section shall not be deemed to repeal, amend or modify any ordinance prohibiting, regulating or licensing canvassers, hawkers, peddlers, transient merchants or any person using the public streets or places for any private business or enterprise or for commercial sales not covered herein. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute any handbill in any place, under any circumstances, which does not have printed on the front or back thereof the name, address and telephone number of the permit holder or the person or organization sponsoring the distribution. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any person distributing handbills or any advertising matter whatsoever to get nearer than 25 feet to a window or door of any residential dwelling unless such person is on a sidewalk, walkway or driveway approaching the residential dwelling. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
a.  Distribute any handbill in the city unless the intended recipient of such handbill is willing to accept it. 
b.  Place a handbill in or on a vehicle, unless an occupant of the vehicle is willing to accept the handbill. 
c.  Distribute a handbill on public property or right-of-way. 
d.  Place a handbill in a mailbox when prohibited by federal postal laws or regulations. 
e.  Distribute any handbill on any property: 
1.  When requested by any person therein not to do so. 
2.  If a sign is placed in a conspicuous position near the entrance to such property reading "No Trespassing", "No Peddlers or Agents", "No Advertisements" or the like. 
3.  That is vacant or unoccupied. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-29. - Highway signs. 
(a)  Allowed uses: 
(1)  General business. 
(2)  Multi-use. 
(3)  Directory. 
(b)  Permit: Required. 
(c)  Maximum height: Fifty feet. 
(1)  Signs over ten feet high shall be constructed and designed to: 
a.  Withstand wind pressure of not less than 30 feet per square foot of area. 
b.  Receive dead load as required in the current building code or other city ordinances. 
(d)  Maximum Area: Two hundred square feet. 
(e)  Placement: 
(1)  Fifteen-foot front setback. 
(2)  Not more than 250 feet from the property line of the adjacent highway or thoroughfare. 
(3)  Thirty foot setback from adjacent nonresidential property. 
(4)  Not less than 100 feet from any other pole sign or 50 feet from any monument sign. 
(5)  Not less than 120 feet from any other highway sign. 
(6)  Not less than 250 feet from adjacent residential property. 
(f)  Maximum number: One per property. 
(g)  Duration: Permanent. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-30. - Minor signs. 
(a)  Allowed uses: 
(1)  Apartment signs. 
(2)  Garage sale signs. 
(3)  Real estate signs. 
(4)  Civic pride. 
(5)  Contractor signs. 
(6)  "Help Wanted" signs. 
(7)  Development directional. 
(8)  Promotional sales, at restaurants only. 
(b)  Permit: Not required. 
Exception: Garage sale signs may not be displayed unless a garage sale permit has been issued. 
(c)  Maximum height: Three feet. 
(d)  Maximum area: Eight square feet. 
(e)  Placement : Private property only. Not allowed on public property. 
(f)  Maximum number : 
(1)  Apartment signs: Three per street frontage. 
(2)  Contractor and "Help Wanted" signs: One sign. 
(3)  Real estate signs: Three signs. 
(4)  Promotional sales signs: Four signs. 
(5)  Garage sale, development directional and civic pride signs: Not applicable. 
(g)  Duration: Not applicable. 
Exception: 
(1)  Garage sale signs must be removed no later than the last day of the sale. 
(2)  Contractor signs may not be erected before work begins and must be removed when the work is completed or stopped. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-31. - Monument signs. 
(a)  Allowed uses: 
(1)  Apartment signs. 
(2)  Bulletin board. 
(3)  Directional. 
(4)  Directory. 
(5)  General business. 
(6)  Menu board. 
(7)  Multi-use. 
(8)  Residential development. 
(b)  Permit: Required. 
(c)  Maximum height : Seven feet, including monument base, measured from ground level. Ground may be bermed or sign placed on a planter a maximum of three feet high as measured from the top of the curb. 
(d)  Maximum area: Seventy square feet. 
Exception: Menu boards, 56 square feet. 
(e)  Placement: 
(1)  Ten-foot front setback. 
(2)  Not less than 50 feet from any pole sign or other monument sign. 
(3)  Not less than 25 feet from adjacent property. 
(f)  Maximum number: One per street frontage. 
Exception: 
(1)  Directory, one per entrance. 
(2)  Menu board, two per drive-thru window. 
(g)  Duration: Permanent. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-32. - New vehicle dealership signage. 
(a)  Allowed uses: The provisions of this section apply only to new vehicle dealerships. 
(b)  Permit: Not required. 
(c)  Maximum height: 
(1)  Inflatable signs: 
a.  One inflatable sign may be tethered by a cord or cable not to exceed 100 feet in length. 
b.  Other inflatable signs may be tethered by a cord or cable not to exceed six feet in length. 
(2)  Hood signs: Height not to exceed distance from vehicle grille to the top of the hood in the open position. 
(d)  Maximum area: 
(1)  Inflatable signs tethered by cord or cable over six feet in length: No dimension may exceed four feet. 
(2)  Inflatable signs tethered by cord or cable six feet or less in length: No dimension may exceed 18 inches. 
(3)  Hood signs: Area as determined by height not to exceed distance from vehicle grille to the top of the hood in the open position and width not to exceed the width of vehicle on which displayed. 
(e)  Placement: 
(1)  Inflatable signs tethered by cord or cable over six feet in length: Anywhere on dealership property such that the inflatable sign will not float above public property or other private property. 
(2)  Other inflatable signs: Only on vehicles parked along the perimeters of dealership property. 
(3)  Hood signs: Only in open hoods of vehicles parked adjacent to one another. 
(4)  Pennants: May be displayed only on the cord or cable over six feet in length which tethers an inflatable sign. 
(5)  Reflective devices: Only on light poles or other permanent stanchions or structural members on dealership property. 
(f)  Maximum number: 
(1)  Inflatable signs tethered by cord or cable over six feet in length: One per property. 
(2)  Other inflatable signs: One per vehicle parked along the perimeter of the property. 
(3)  Hood signs: No more than eight vehicles may be used for display of hood signs. 
(4)  Reflective devices: Four per property. 
(g)  Duration: 
(1)  Inflatable signs 18 inches or less in diameter: Any time. 
(2)  Inflatable signs over 18 inches in diameter: Weekends only. 
(3)  Hood signs: Weekends only. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-33. - Pennants. 
(a)  Allowed uses: General business. 
(b)  Permit: Grand opening permit required. 
(c)  Maximum height: Not applicable. 
(d)  Maximum area: Not applicable. 
(e)  Placement: May not be placed in such a manner as to cause a hazard or inconvenience to vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(f)  Maximum number: Not applicable. 
(g)  Duration: Two weeks; allowed only for the duration of grand opening permit, issued within 90 days of issuance of certificate of occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-34. - Pole signs. 
(a)  Allowed uses: 
(1)  Bulletin boards. 
(2)  Directory. 
(3)  General business. 
(4)  Multi-use. 
(5)  Scoreboards. 
(b)  Permit: Required. 
Exception: Scoreboards, not required. 
(c)  Maximum height : Twenty-five feet. 
(1)  Signs over ten feet high shall be constructed and designed to: 
a.  Withstand wind pressure of not less than 30 feet per square foot of sign area. 
b.  Receive dead load as required in the current building code or other city ordinances. 
(d)  Maximum area: Sixty-four square feet. 
Exception: Multi-use signs may not exceed 150 square feet, provided that not more than 25 percent of the sign's area may be used as an identification sign. 
(e)  Placement: 
(1)  Fifteen-foot front setback. 
(2)  Not less than 30 feet from adjacent nonresidential property. 
(3)  Not less than 50 feet from adjacent residential property. 
(4)  Not less than 100 feet from any other pole sign or 50 feet from any monument sign. 
(f)  Maximum number: 
(1)  Multi-use signs: One per street frontage. 
(2)  Scoreboards: One per property. 
(3)  Other pole signs: One for each 200 feet of street frontage, or: 
a.  Sites of three acres and less than eight acres: Two signs. 
b.  Sites of eight or more acres: Three signs. 
(g)  Duration: Permanent. 
(h)  Other requirements: 
(1)  Poles must be set in concrete bases or footings. 
(2)  Pole signs shall have no guys or braces attached to the ground or to other structures. 
(3)  Internally illuminated pole signs shall be constructed of noncombustible materials, except that the sign faces may be made of plastic or other slow-burning materials if supported by noncombustible materials only. 
(4)  The use of wood, non-painted steel supports (except for corten or similar steel) or other materials is prohibited unless specifically approved by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04; Ord. No. 1978, § 9, 4-4-06) 
Sec. 16A-35. - Political signs. 
(a)  Private property. 
(1)  A real property owner may place, cause, permit, suffer, allow or maintain a political sign on private property. 
(2)  Any sign on private property as provided in this subsection, may not exceed eight feet in height and shall not exceed 36 square feet in total surface area. 
(b)  Public property/right-of-way. 
(1)  It is an offense for any person to leave any political or electioneering sign or literature on public property, or public right-of-way except as provided in subsection (c) as a polling place. 
(c)  Election polling places and public property. 
(1)  Electioneering at polling locations. 
a.  Regulations. A person may place a political sign or electioneering sign on the premises of a polling place during a voting period, as defined herein in the area(s) designated at a polling place set forth in Figure 1, 2, 3 or 4; 
1.  This restriction shall not apply to electioneering signs that are attached solely to vehicles that are lawfully parked at the premises of a polling place, so long as the sign dimensions do not exceed eight square feet in area and three feet in height, including any supporting poles. 
2.  This restriction shall not apply to electioneering signs that are attached to a tent used by a candidate at a polling place, so long as the sign dimensions do not exceed eight square feet in area and three feet in height, including any supporting poles. 
(2)  It is an offense for any person to place an electioneering sign at a polling place that exceeds eight square feet in area and three feet in height, including any supporting poles. 
(3)  It is an offense for any person to attach, place or otherwise affix any electioneering sign, literature or material to any building, tree, shrub, pole or other improvement on public property used as a polling place. 
(4)  It is an offense if any candidate or responsible person causes, permits, suffers or allows a sign to remain at a polling place more than 72 hours after the close of voting on election day or run-off election day. 
(5)  In addition to imposing any criminal penalty, electioneering sign(s) located in violation of this section may be removed and disposed of by the building official or other election official in charge of the polling place. 
(d)  Nothing contained in this article shall impair any person(s) rights to engage in constitutional protected free speech or canvassing during a voting period or in other public forum or limited public forum subject to the restrictions set forth herein. 
(e)  That any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions or terms of this section, as amended hereby, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, shall be subjected to a fine not to exceed the sum of $250.00 for each offense; and each and every occurrence and day such violation is continued shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. 
Figure 1 - Duncanville Library, 201 James Collins 


Figure 2 - Reed Middle School, 530 E. Freeman St. 


Figure 3 - Fairmeadows Elementary, 101 E. Fairmeadows Dr. 


Figure 4 - Byrd Middle School, 1040 W. Wheatland Rd. 


(f)  That any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions or terms of this section, as amended hereby, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, shall be subjected to a fine not to exceed the sum of $250.00 for each offense; and each and every day such violation is continued shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04; Ord. No. 2106, § 5, 2-16-10; Ord. No. 2193, § 3, 3-19-13; Ord. No. 2221, § 1, 4-15-14; Ord. No. 2262, § 2, 12-1-15) 
Sec. 16A-36. - Searchlights. 
(a)  Allowed uses: General business. 
(b)  Permit: Not required. 
(c)  Maximum height: Not applicable. 
(d)  Maximum area: Not applicable. 
(e)  Placement: On private property only. 
(f)  Maximum number: One per property. 
(g)  Duration: Maximum single-use period of 14 days during a calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-37. - Wall signs. 
(a)  Allowed uses: 
(1)  General business. 
(2)  Apartment signs. 
(3)  Real estate signs. 
(4)  Menu board. 
(5)  Identification signs. 
(6)  Multi-use signs. 
(7)  Bulletin board. 
(8)  Directional signs. 
(9)  Directories. 
(10)  Scoreboards. 
(11)  Signs erected in designated sign areas shall be limited to uses specified by the building official. 
(b)  Permit: Required. 
Exception: Directional signs and scoreboards, not required. 
(c)  Maximum height: Four feet. 
(d)  Maximum area: 
(1)  The total square footage of all wall signs on a structure may not exceed the horizontal linear measurement of the display frontage of that structure. When the display frontage includes more than one wall, the total square footage of all wall signs on any one wall of the structure may not exceed the horizontal linear measurement of the wall upon which erected. 
Exceptions to maximum area: 
A.  The area of all wall signs on a structure exceeding 90,000 square feet area and housing a single occupant or business entity shall be as follows: 
Building Height Maximum Sign Height Maximum Signage Length as 
Percentage of Display 
Frontage 0 - 20 feet 4 feet 75% 21 - 30 feet 6 feet 60% over 30 feet 8 feet 50%  
    No more than 20 percent of wall signage erected on such structures may advertise businesses or services other than the main occupant of the structure. 
B.  For businesses the interior area of which is 15,000 square feet or less, when the display frontage of the business is set back from the street which it faces, wall sign dimensions may be increased as follows: 
Setback From Street Percent Increase in Area Maximum Signage

Display Frontage 150 feet or greater 125% 75% 250 feet or greater 150% 75% 350 feet or greater 175% 75%  
    Maximum signage length as a percentage of any wall not used to determine display frontage is 50 percent. 
C.  Directional signs, eight square feet area. 
D.  Menu boards, 64 square feet. The area of one wall sign used as a menu board shall not count against the total square footage of wall signs allowed on a structure. 
E.  The building official shall specify the maximum area of wall signs erected in designated sign areas. 
(2)  Detached canopies, such as those found at gas stations, and other detached accessory structures, are considered separate structures from the main structure for the purpose of determining area allowance. The area of wall signage allowed on canopies or accessory buildings attached to the main structure shall be calculated based on the horizontal linear measurement of the display frontage of the main structure as specified in subsection 16A-37(d)(1) above. 
(e)  Placement. 
(1)  Walls or designated sign areas of structures, or mansard roofs. Signs placed on a mansard roof may not extend above the top of the roof. 
(2)  Wall signs may not extend more than 12 inches away from the wall on which they are erected or attached. 
(3)  Wall signs used as menu boards may only be displayed on the side and/or rear walls of a structure. 
(f)  Maximum number: 
(1)  Ten per structure. 
Exceptions: 
a.  Scoreboards: One per property. 
b.  Canopies and accessory buildings: One per side. 
(g)  Duration: Permanent. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04; Ord. No. 1978, § 10, 4-4-06; Ord. No. 2106, § 6, 2-16-10; Ord. No. 2130, § 2, 11-16-10) 
Sec. 16A-38. - Window signs. 
(a)  Allowed uses: Unrestricted. 
(b)  Permit: Not required. 
(c)  Maximum height: Not applicable. 
(d)  Maximum area: Signs may not cover over 40 percent of the glazed area of any separately framed window or door. 
(e)  Placement: Interior or exterior surfaces of windows and/or glass doors or inside a structure within five feet of windows or doors. 
(f)  Maximum number: Not applicable. 
(g)  Duration: Not applicable. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 16A-39. - Murals. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, in addition to the definitions provided by section 16A-5 of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Alter. To change in any way or to any extent the appearance, size, shape, colors, subject, designs, figures, elements or pictures of a mural. 
    Dilapidated or deteriorated condition. 
(1)  Where any part of a mural is chipped, flaked, faded, broken, damaged, defective, missing, torn, bent, dented, cracked, splintered, twisted, inoperable, leaning or at angles other than those at which erected; or 
(2)  Where the message or wording is faded or can no longer be clearly read; or 
(3)  Where any part of the mural is not in compliance with the requirements of the building, electrical, property maintenance or other codes or ordinances adopted by the city. 
    Mural. A painting, design or artistic work applied to an exterior wall or to a fence for aesthetic purposes. 
    Restore. To return a mural to its exact original appearance and quality from a dilapidated or deteriorated condition. 
(b)  No person shall apply, install, erect, or restore a mural, as defined hereinabove, without first having a valid sign permit issued in accordance with this chapter. The building official shall, prior to issuing a permit, obtain a recommendation from the Keep Duncanville Beautiful Board, or its successor. 
(c)  The maximum height, area, number, and duration requirements applicable to other types of signs shall not apply to murals. The design, location and placement of a mural must be approved by the building official after a recommendation by the Keep Duncanville Beautiful Board, or its successor, prior to the issuance of a permit. The permit will not be issued until 30 days after final approval by the Keep Duncanville Beautiful Board so the city council may have an opportunity to review and intervene in the issuance of any permit. 
(d)  Standards of construction and content. 
(1)  Murals shall be composed of permanent materials and applied only to permanent surfaces. Murals shall not be applied to any fabric or temporary surface, and all materials used must be resistant to the short-term effects of exposure to the elements. 
(2)  Removal of a mural must be accomplished by physical removal from wall or fence of the paint or other material of which the mural is composed, and/or by covering the mural with paint or other material. In both cases, either by physical removal or covering, it must be rendered completely invisible and must maintain the structural and architectural integrity of the structure upon which the mural was applied. 
(e)  Murals may contain subject matter consistent with the theme of a business but may not contain branded products, brand names, business names, or logos. 
(f)  Other regulations and requirements . 
(1)  Maintenance responsibility and standards. At all times during and after application, murals shall be considered the property of the owner and/or occupant of the structure to which applied, and said owner and/or occupant shall be responsible for maintenance and upkeep of the mural. 
(2)  All murals shall be kept in a proper state of repair and preservation. It is a violation of this section to own, keep or maintain any mural in a dilapidated or deteriorated condition or to permit or allow a mural to be kept in such condition. 
(3)  If the building official determines a mural to be in dilapidated or deteriorated condition, the mural shall be restored or removed by the owner and/or occupant of the structure to which it is applied. 
(4)  The building official may cause the removal of any mural that is not maintained in accordance with the provisions of this section. A mural which is kept, maintained or allowed to remain in a dilapidated or deteriorated condition is hereby declared to be a nuisance. Upon the failure of the owner and/or occupant of the premises on which the mural is located to repair or remove the mural following ten days notice thereof, the city may cause the removal of the mural. The owner and/or occupant shall pay all expenses incurred by the city incident to such removal. In the event of the failure of the owner and/or occupant to remit to the city the expenses incurred in the abatement of the nuisance, a lien may be placed on and against the property on which the mural is removed. Such lien shall bear interest at the rate of ten percent per annum and shall be a first and prior lien, second only to liens for taxes and paving assessments. 
(Ord. No. 1909, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Chapter 16B - SMOKING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2263, § 1, adopted January 19, 2016 repealed ch. 16B, arts. I-III, §§ 16B-1-16B-10, in its entirety; and enacted a new ch. 16B, to read as set out herein. Previously ch. 16B pertained to similar subject matter, and was derived from Ord. No. 1196, § 1, adopted June 19, 1989 and Ord. No. 2120, § 1, adopted August 3, 2010. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; miscellaneous offenses and provisions, ch. 12. 

ARTICLE I. - SMOKING REGULATED 

Sec. 16B-1. - Short title. 
    This article shall hereafter be known and cited as the "Smoke-free air ordinance of 2016." 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-2. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following words and phrases have the meanings ascribed to them in this article: 
    Bar means an establishment which has more than 51 percent of its annual gross sales from alcoholic beverages and which is devoted to the serving of alcoholic beverages pursuant to the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code for consumption by guests on the premises and in which the serving of food is only incidental to the consumption of such beverages and where minors are not allowed admittance unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. Food establishments that contain a bar are not considered a "bar." 
    Business means a sole proprietorship, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other business entity, either for-profit or not-for-profit, including retail establishments where goods or services are sold; professional corporations and other entities where legal, medical, dental, engineering, architectural, or other professional services are delivered; and private clubs. 
    Electronic or digital smoking device means any product containing or delivering nicotine or any other substance intended for human consumption that can be used by a person to simulate smoking through inhalation of vapor or aerosol from the product. The term includes any such device, whether manufactured, distributed, marketed, or sold as an e-cigarette, e-cigar, e-pipe, e-hookah, or vape pen, or under any other product name or descriptor. 
    Employee means a person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct or indirect monetary wages or profit, and a person who volunteers his or her services for a nonprofit entity. 
    Employer means a person, business, partnership, association, corporation, including a municipal corporation, trust, or nonprofit entity that employs the services of one or more individual persons. 
    Enclosed area means all space between a floor and a ceiling that is bounded on at least two sides by walls, doorways, or windows, whether open or closed. A wall includes any retractable divider, garage door, or other physical barrier, whether temporary or permanent and whether or not containing openings of any kind. 
    Health-care facility means an office or institution providing care or treatment of diseases, whether physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical, physiological, or psychological conditions, including but not limited to, hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals or other clinics, including weight control clinics, nursing homes, long-term care facilities, homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, and offices of surgeons, chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, psychiatrists, dentists, and all specialists within these professions. This definition shall include all waiting rooms, hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms, and wards within health-care facilities. 
    Place of employment means an area under the control of a public or private employer, including, but not limited to, work areas, private offices, employee lounges, restrooms, conference rooms, meeting rooms, classrooms, employee cafeterias, hallways, construction sites, temporary offices, and vehicles. A private residence is not a "place of employment" unless it is used as a child-care, adult day care, or health-care facility. 
    Playground means any park or recreational area designed in part to be used by children that has play or sports equipment installed or that has been designated or landscaped for play or sports activities, or any similar facility located on public or private school grounds or on city grounds. 
    Private club means an organization, whether incorporated or not, which is the owner, lessee, or occupant of a building or portion thereof used exclusively for club purposes at all times, which is operated solely for a recreational, fraternal, social, patriotic, political, benevolent, or athletic purpose, but not for pecuniary gain, and which only sells alcoholic beverages incidental to its operation. The affairs and management of the organization are conducted by a board of directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the members at an annual meeting. The organization has established bylaws and/or a constitution to govern its activities. The organization has been granted an exemption from the payment of federal income tax as a club under 26 U.S.C. Section 501. 
    Public event means an event which is open to and may be attended by the general public, including but not limited to, such events as concerts, fairs, farmers' markets, festivals, parades, performances, and other exhibitions, regardless of any fee or age requirement. 
    Public place means an area to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted, including but not limited to, bars, educational facilities, financial institutions, gaming facilities, health-care facilities, hotels and motels, laundromats, parking structures, public transportation vehicles and facilities to include all ticketing, boarding, and waiting area, reception areas, restaurants, retail food production and marketing establishments, retail service establishments, retail stores, shopping malls, sports arenas, theaters, and waiting rooms. A private residence is not a "public place" unless it is used as a child-care, adult day care, or health-care facility. 
    Recreational area means any public or private area open to the public for recreational purposes, whether or not any fee for admission is charged, including but not limited to, amusement parks, athletic fields, fairgrounds, gardens, golf courses, parks, plazas, skate parks, swimming pools, trails, and zoos. 
    Restaurant means an eating establishment, including but not limited to, coffee shops, cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias, which gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests, or employees, as well as kitchens and catering facilities in which food is prepared on the premises for serving elsewhere. The term "restaurant" shall include a bar area within the restaurant. 
    Retail electronic smoking device store means a store used primarily for the sale of electronic or digital cigarettes or substances used in those or similar devices to produce inhalable vapors and in which the sale of other products is incidental and where 80 percent of quarterly sales are from the sale of these devices and/or substances. 
    Retail tobacco store or tobacco store means a retail store where 75 percent of quarterly sales are from tobacco products and accessories, to include electronic or digital cigarettes, and in which the sale of other products is merely incidental. 
    Service line means an indoor or outdoor line in which one or more persons are waiting for or receiving service of any kind, whether or not the service involves the exchange of money, including but not limited to, ATM lines, concert lines, food vendor lines, movie ticket lines, and sporting event lines. 
    Shopping mall means an enclosed or unenclosed public walkway or hall area that serves to connect retail or professional establishments. 
    Smoking means inhaling, exhaling, burning, or carrying any lighted or heated cigar, cigarette, or pipe, or any other lighted or heated tobacco or plant product intended for inhalation, including hookahs and marijuana, whether natural or synthetic, in any manner or in any form. "Smoking" also includes the use of an electronic smoking device which creates an aerosol or vapor, in any manner or in any form, or the use of any oral smoking device for the purpose of circumventing the prohibition of smoking in this article. 
    Sports arena means a place where people assemble to engage in physical exercise, participate in athletic competition, or witness sports or other events, including sports pavilions, stadiums, gymnasiums, health spas, boxing arenas, swimming pools, roller and ice rinks, and bowling alleys. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-3. - Application of article to city-owned facilities and property. 
    All enclosed areas, including buildings and vehicles owned, leased, or operated by the city, as well as all outdoor property adjacent to such buildings and under the control of the city, shall be subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-4. - Enclosed public places. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in all enclosed public places within the city, including but not limited to, the following places: 
(1)  Galleries, libraries, and museums; 
(2)  Areas available to the general public in businesses and nonprofit entities patronized by the public, including but not limited to, financial institutions, laundromats, professional offices, and retail service establishments; 
(3)  Child-care and adult day-care facilities; 
(4)  Convention facilities and meeting areas; 
(5)  Educational facilities, both public and private; 
(6)  Elevators and escalators; 
(7)  Gaming facilities, including but not limited to bowling and billiard facilities; 
(8)  Health-care facilities; 
(9)  Hotels and motels; 
(10)  Lobbies, hallways, and other common areas in apartment buildings, condominiums, trailer parks, nursing homes, assisted living and independent living facilities, and other multiple-unit residential facilities; 
(11)  Parking structures; 
(12)  Polling places; 
(13)  Private and semi-private rooms in nursing homes; 
(14)  Public transportation vehicles, including buses and taxicabs, under the authority of the city, and ticket, boarding, and waiting areas of public transportation facilities, including bus, train, and airport facilities; 
(15)  Restaurants and bars; 
(16)  Restrooms, lobbies, reception areas, hallways, and other common-use areas; 
(17)  Retail stores, except as provided in section 16B-9(3); 
(18)  Rooms, chambers, places of meeting or public assembly, including school buildings, under the control of an agency, board, commission, committee or council of the city or a political subdivision of the state, to the extent the place is subject to the jurisdiction of the city; 
(19)  Service lines; 
(20)  Shopping malls; 
(21)  Sports arenas, including enclosed places in outdoor arenas; and 
(22)  Theaters and other facilities primarily used for exhibiting motion pictures, stage dramas, lectures, musical recitals, or other similar performances. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-5. - Enclosed places of employment. 
(a)  Smoking shall be prohibited in all enclosed areas of places of employment without exception. This includes, without limitation, common work areas, auditoriums, classrooms, conference and meeting rooms, private offices, elevators, hallways, medical facilities, cafeterias, employee lounges, stairs, restrooms, vehicles, and all other enclosed facilities. 
(b)  This prohibition on smoking shall be communicated to all existing employees by the effective date of this article and to all prospective employees upon their application for employment. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-6. - Private clubs. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in all private clubs, except as provided in section 16B-9(4). 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-7. - Enclosed residential facilities. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in the following enclosed residential facilities: 
(1)  All private and semi-private rooms in nursing homes; and 
(2)  All hotel and motel guest rooms. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-8. - Outdoor public places. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in the following outdoor places: 
(1)  Within a reasonable distance of 15 feet outside entrances, operable windows, and ventilation systems of enclosed areas where smoking is prohibited, so as to prevent tobacco smoke from entering those areas; 
(2)  Within a reasonable distance of 15 feet outside entrances, operable windows, and ventilation systems of buildings owned, leased, or operated by the city, and that is under the control of the city; 
(3)  In, and within 15 feet of, outdoor seating or serving areas of restaurants and bars; 
(4)  In outdoor shopping malls, including parking structures; 
(5)  In all outdoor arenas, stadiums, and amphitheaters. Smoking shall also be prohibited in, and within 15 feet of, bleachers and grandstands for use by spectators at sporting and other public events; 
(6)  In, and within 15 feet of, all outdoor playgrounds; 
(7)  In, and within 15 feet of, all outdoor public transportation stations, platforms, and shelters under the authority of the city; 
(8)  In all outdoor service lines, including lines in which service is obtained by persons in vehicles, such as service that is provided by bank tellers, parking lot attendants, and toll takers. In lines in which service is obtained by persons in vehicles, smoking is prohibited by both pedestrians and persons in vehicles, but only within 15 feet of the point of service; and 
(9)  In outdoor common areas of apartment buildings, condominiums, trailer parks, retirement facilities, nursing homes, and other multiple-unit residential facilities, except in designated smoking areas, not to exceed 25 percent of the total outdoor common area, which must be located at least 15 feet outside entrances, operable windows, and ventilation systems of enclosed areas where smoking is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-9. - Where smoking not regulated. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article to the contrary, the following areas shall be exempt from provisions of this article: 
(1)  Private residences, unless used as a child-care, adult day-care, or health-care facility; 
(2)  Private automobiles; 
(3)  Retail tobacco stores, cigar stores, and retail electronic smoking device stores for sampling of the products sold in such stores, so long as such smoking does not cause smoke or "aerosol/vapor" to cross into other areas where smoking is not allowed. 
(4)  Private clubs dedicated to the service of veterans of the United States military and their families, incorporated as a non-profit corporation, located and established within the corporate limits of the city prior to January 1, 1975. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-10. - Declaration of establishment or outdoor area as nonsmoking. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, an owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of an establishment, facility, or outdoor area may declare that entire establishment, facility, or outdoor area as a nonsmoking place. Smoking shall be prohibited in any place in which a sign conforming to the requirements of section 16B-11 is posted. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-11. - Posting of signs and removal of ashtrays. 
    The owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of a place of employment, public place, private club, or residential facility where smoking is prohibited by this article shall: 
(1)  Clearly and conspicuously post "no smoking" signs or the international "no smoking" symbol (consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it) in that place; 
(2)  Clearly and conspicuously post at every entrance to that place a sign stating that smoking is prohibited or, in the case of outdoor places, clearly and conspicuously post "no smoking" signs in appropriate locations as determined by the city health inspector or an authorized designee; 
(3)  Clearly and conspicuously post on every vehicle that constitutes a place of employment under this article at least one sign, visible from the exterior of the vehicle, stating that smoking is prohibited; 
(4)  Remove all ashtrays from any area where smoking is prohibited by this article, except for ashtrays displayed for sale and not for use on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-12. - Nonretaliation; nonwaiver of rights. 
(a)  No person or employer shall discharge, refuse to hire, or in any manner retaliate against an employee, applicant for employment, customer, or resident of a multiple-unit residential facility because that employee, applicant, customer, or resident exercises any rights afforded by this article or reports or attempts to prosecute a violation of this article. Notwithstanding section 16B-16, violation of this subsection shall be a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00 for each violation. 
(b)  An employee who works in a setting where an employer allows smoking does not waive or otherwise surrender any legal rights the employee may have against the employer or any other party. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-13. - Possession, purchase, consumption or receipt of electronic cigarettes or e-cigarettes and/or liquid nicotine by minors prohibited. 
(a)  A person who is younger than 18 years of age commits an offense if the individual: 
(1)  Possesses, purchases, consumes or accepts an electronic cigarette, e-cigarette or liquid nicotine; or 
(2)  Falsely represents himself or herself to be 18 years of age or older by displaying proof of age that is false, fraudulent or not actually proof of the individual's own age in order to obtain possession of, purchase or receive an electronic cigarette, e-cigarette or liquid nicotine. 
(b)  It shall be a defense to prosecution for a violation of this section if the individual younger than 18 years of age possessed the electronic cigarette, e-cigarette or liquid nicotine in the presence of: 
(1)  An adult parent, a guardian or a spouse of the individual; or 
(2)  An employer of the individual, if possession or receipt of the electronic cigarette, e-cigarette or liquid nicotine is required in the performance of the employee's duties as an employee. 
(c)  It shall also be a defense to prosecution for a violation of this section that the individual younger than 18 years of age is participating in an inspection or test of compliance in accordance with section 161.088, Health and Safety Code. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-14. - Sale of electronic cigarette or e-cigarette or liquid nicotine to persons younger than 18 years of age prohibited; proof of age required. 
(a)  A person or retailer commits an offense if the person or retailer with criminal negligence: 
(1)  Sells, gives or causes to be sold or given an electronic cigarette or e-cigarette or liquid nicotine to someone who is younger than 18 years of age; or 
(2)  Sells, gives or causes to be sold or given an electronic cigarette or e-cigarette or liquid nicotine to another person who intends to deliver it to someone who is younger than 18 years of age. 
(b)  If an offense under this section occurs in connection with a sale by an employee of the owner of a store in which electronic cigarettes, e-cigarettes and/or liquid nicotine is/are sold at retail, the employee is criminally responsible for the offense and is subject to prosecution. 
(c)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (a)(1) that the person to whom the electronic cigarette, e-cigarette or liquid nicotine was sold or given presented to the defendant apparently valid proof of identification. 
(d)  A proof of identification satisfies the requirements of subsection if it contains a physical description and photograph consistent with the person's appearance, purports to establish that the person is 18 years of age or older and was issued by a governmental agency. The proof of identification may include a driver's license issued by this state or another state, a passport or an identification card issued by a state or the federal government. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-15. - Enforcement. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced by the city health inspector, peace officer, or an authorized designee. 
(b)  Notice of the provisions of this article shall be given to all applicants for a certificate of occupancy in the city. 
(c)  Any citizen who desires to register a complaint under this article may initiate enforcement with the city health inspector, peace officer, or an authorized designee. 
(d)  The health department or their designees shall, while an establishment is undergoing otherwise mandated inspections, inspect for compliance with this article. 
(e)  An owner, manager, operator, or employee of an area regulated by this article shall direct a person who is smoking in violation of this article to extinguish or turn off the product being smoked. If the person does not stop smoking, the owner, manager, operator, or employee shall refuse service and shall immediately ask the person to leave the premises. If the person in violation refuses to leave the premises, the owner, manager, operator, or employee shall contact a law enforcement agency. 
(f)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, an employee or private citizen may bring legal action to enforce this article. 
(g)  In addition to the remedies provided by the provisions of this section, the city health inspector or authorized designee or any person aggrieved by the failure of the owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of a public place or a place of employment to comply with the provisions of this article may apply for injunctive relief to enforce those provisions in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-16. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited by the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an infraction, punishable by: 
(1)  A fine not exceeding $100.00 for a first violation; 
(2)  A fine not exceeding $200.00 for a second violation within one year; 
(3)  A fine not exceeding $500.00 for each additional violation within one year. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in section 16B-5, a person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment and who fails to comply with the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an infraction, punishable by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00 for each violation. 
(c)  In addition to the fines established by this section, violation of this article by a person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment may result in the suspension or revocation by the city health inspector, or an authorized designee, of any permit or license issued to the person for the premises on which the violation occurred. 
(d)  Violation of this article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, which may be abated by the city health inspector, peace officer, or authorized designee by restraining order, preliminary and permanent injunction, or other means provided for by law, and the city may take action to recover the costs of the nuisance abatement. 
(e)  Each day on which a violation of this article occurs shall be considered a separate and distinct violation. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-17. - Effective date. 
    This article shall be effective on May 1, 2016. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Sec. 16B-18. - Severability. 
    If any section or portion of this article is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by a decision of a court of competent jurisdiction, that section or portion shall be deemed severable and shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of the article. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-19-16) 
Chapter 17 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Burning of rubbish, leaves, etc., in streets or alleys, § 9-1; obstruction of crossings by trains, § 16-2; maintenance of crossings, § 16-3; required signals at crossings, § 16-4; traffic, ch. 19; zoning, app. A; subdivision regulations, app. B. 

Sec. 17-1. - Master street plan. 
    (Repealed by Ord. No. 1200, §§ 2, 3, 6-19-89; See now app. B, Subdivision regulations.) 
Sec. 17-2. - Street numbering for buildings. 
(a)  Base line designated. A system of street numbering is hereby established and a base line is designated as follows: 
Main Street and Center Street shall be the base lines for the purpose of house numbering and each street running east and west, or substantially in that course, shall begin, for the purpose of such numbering, at the east or west side of Main Street, as the case may be, with the number of 100 increasing block by block from such initial point to the corporate limits, as it now exists, or may be hereafter extended; and each street running north and south, or substantially with that course, shall begin at the north or south side of Center Street, as the case may be, with the number of 100 increasing block by block from such initial point to the corporate limits, as they now exist, or may hereafter be extended. The odd numbers shall appear on the north side of, and the even numbers on the south side of the street running east and easterly from Main Street, and the odd numbers shall appear on the west side of, and the even numbers on the east side of, the other streets. 
(b)  Specifications. The official number required by this section shall be of durable material which will not tarnish, fade, corrode or peel on account of the action of the elements and shall be of a color contrasting to its background. Numbers shall be a minimum of three inches in height and visible from the public street, alleyway and/or access. Houses not visible from the street shall also be numbered visible at street entrance(s) to the property. 
    Nothing herein shall prohibit any number from being printed by any person when such character of material is used as will, in the judgment of the building inspector, be equal in strength, durability and service to the metal number required by this section. 
(c)  Placement by owner, etc., required; application. 
(1)  Each owner, agent of the owner, or the occupant of any house situated in the city shall display or permit to be displayed, in a conspicuous place, an official house number so that it may be plainly visible from both the front and rear of said building or dwelling. 
(2)  Buildings and dwellings without rear entry ways shall not be required to place numbers on the rear of their premises. 
(3)  Numbers printed on the curb shall not meet the requirements of this section. 
(d)  Numbering within building complexes. A building of multiple structures or occupancies must have an official number assigned to each building and each unit within the building. The official number assigned to each building must be conspicuously posted and displayed both at the front and rear of the building, if the building design permits, or so displayed that it is visible, where possible, from the nearest vehicular access. The official number for each unit within the building must be conspicuously posted on the unit. 
(e)  Diagram of multiple structures. If, in a complex of multiple structures or occupancies, the number is not visible from the street or alleyway by reason of design, a sign directory shall be placed in front of the building and a diagram of the complex shall be furnished by the owner to the fire and police departments. This shall be updated and departments notified upon business changes. 
(Ord. No. 137, §§ 1, 2, 6-25-56; Ord. No. 794, § 1, 4-21-80) 
Cross reference- Buildings generally, ch. 5 
Sec. 17-3. - Placing trash or debris on or failing to remove same from streets, alleys, easements, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place any trash or debris upon any public street, alley, drainage or other public easement in the city. It shall also be an offense for any person to fail to remove trash or debris from any street, alley, drainage or other public easement in the city after being requested to do so by an official of the city. 
(Ord. No. 259, § 1, 9-24-62; Ord. No. 493, § 1, 3-8-71) 
Cross reference- Removal of construction trash and debris from streets and alleys, § 5-5; similar provisions with reference to vacant lots and private property, § 12-6; throwing trash or rubbish from vehicles, spilling vehicle loads, etc., § 19-7. 
Sec. 17-4. - Prohibiting hockey, soccer and basketball goals or other obstructions within public rights-of-way. 
    No person shall place, construct or erect any pole or structure with a hockey, soccer or basketball goal, rim, hoop or other device affixed thereto designed or intended to be used for or readily adaptable for athletic or sporting purposes, or any other obstruction, upon, along, or across any public right-of-way or other public easement in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1788, § 1, 5-7-02) 
Sec. 17-5. - New street construction. 
(a)  No street having a right-of-way with a width in excess of 60 feet shall be constructed in or within 100 feet of any single-family or duplex dwelling district where such right-of-way is within 100 feet of a lot having a dwelling thereon, unless a public hearing is first held by the city council to consider the question of whether such street should be constructed and approval granted. The public hearing shall be held only after notice of such hearing is first published in the official newspaper of the city and mailed by first class mail to all owners of property within 500 feet of the right-of-way of such proposed street, which notice shall be published and sent before the fifteenth day day before the date of the public hearing. The notice shall be deemed sent when deposited in the United States mail, postage paid, and addressed to the owner as indicated by the most recently approved tax roll. The city shall erect signage informing of the project plans for a minimum of 15 days prior to the date of the public hearing. 
(b)  This section shall only apply to new street and roadway construction and shall not apply in the following circumstances: 
(1)  Streets and roadways set forth in plats, replats, site plans, and other development permits; 
(2)  Private streets; and 
(3)  Street widening, repair, repaving, or maintenance projects on preexisting streets. 
(Ord. No. 1919, § 1, 2-15-05) 
Secs. 17-6-17-13. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET IMPROVEMENTS BY PRIVATE CONTRACTORS 

Sec. 17-14. - Permit required. 
    No person shall construct, reconstruct, alter, repair, remove, replace, pave, repave, surface, or resurface any walk, drive, curb, gutter, paved area, street, or appurtenance on public 
property in the city, without first obtaining from the building inspector a permit to do so. Such permit may be issued upon payment of a permit fee together with inspection fees as may be established by appropriate resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1202, § 14, 7-17-89) 
Sec. 17-15. - Application for permit. 
    To obtain a permit as required by this article, a contractor bonded in accord with this article, or his authorized representative, shall file with the building inspector an application in writing therefor on a form to be furnished for that purpose. Each application for a permit shall describe the abutting property adjacent to which the proposed work on public property is to be done, either by lot, block or tract and house number, location on the street or similar description which will readily identify and definitely locate the site of the proposed work. Each applicant shall give such other pertinent information as shall be required by the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 275, § 2, 2-25-63) 
Sec. 17-16. - Bond generally. 
(a)  No person shall construct, reconstruct, or repair any sidewalk, curb, gutter or driveway approach or public street in the city, without executing and delivering to the city a bond in the sum of $2,000.00, payable to the City of Duncanville, Dallas County, Texas, with a good and sufficient corporate surety thereon, authorized to do business in the state. 
(b)  The surety bond required by this section shall be conditioned that all work be done in a good and workmanlike manner, and that the principal shall faithfully and strictly comply with the city's specifications and with the terms of this article and such ordinances, resolutions or regulations as may be passed by the city council relating to the construction, reconstruction or repair of sidewalks, curbs, gutters or driveway approaches, or public streets, and that the city shall be fully indemnified and be held whole and harmless from any and all costs, expenses or damages, whether real or asserted, on account of any injury done to any person or property in the prosecution of such work, or that may arise out of or be occasioned by the performance of such work. Such bond shall be conditioned further that the person performing the work shall, without additional cost to the person for whom the work was done, maintain all such construction for a period of one year from the date of such construction, reconstruction or repair, to the satisfaction of the director of public works of the city, and shall reconstruct or repair same to the satisfaction of the director of public works at any time within one year after the construction, reconstruction or repair of such facility, and after ten days' notice from the director of public works to reconstruct or repair the same, and the opinion of the director of public works as to the necessity of such reconstruction or repair shall be binding on the parties thereto. Such bond shall, for such purpose, be enforced for one year after construction, reconstruction or repair of such facility, and one recovery shall not exhaust the bond, but such bond shall be a continual obligation against the surety thereon until the entire amount therein provided for shall have been exhausted. 
(c)  In case the bond provided for in this section shall be decreased on account of any recoveries which may be obtained, arising out of the violation of any conditions of the same, the city council shall require, upon notice to it of such fact, an additional bond to be given by such person in accordance with this section, in an amount sufficient, when added to the exhausted amount of the original bond, to be at all times equal to the sum of $2,000.00.
